Re Ryerson School Specifications.

On receipt of same I immediately passed them on to several local contractors. Since then I have had several enquiries from prospective tenderers that they are not very clear as to the heating specification, and would ask you to look over same and explain a little more fully. For instance you will notice only one hot air pipe from furnace to school room on north side and two cold air ducts on the south side, which the heating men claim is not enough to heat that space. Then there are two registers in the hall way. Please specify whether they are both hot or cold or one of each. I presume they are both hot.

The furnace has lots of capacity but it doesn't seem to be properly distributed. If this can be fixed up I can let the tenderers in town know before they put in their bids, as I do not think there will be any from places outside of Parry Sound Town.

I would also recommend that the whole basement be excavated, as it would not cost any more than to take earth put. You will notice that the centre wall will cost more than by putting the south outside wall down to the full depth, and have a running beam in centre on brick piers.

The full size basement is almost necessary for storing fuel etc. It might also be added that bell from old school be hung in new tower as it would be cheaper when construction work is going on.

The building will face East.

I am Your Obedient Servant,

"The more you wash it the better it looks."

PARIPAN is not just an Enamel, but a Lacquer Enamel. The Glossy has an exceptionally brilliant surface. The Flat has a dull silk sheen which makes it "the acme of artistic decoration." Both are equally washable.

The cost of Paripan when compared with ordinary paint should be about 15 per cent. more for three-coat work. We recommend for best work four-coat process.

The following figures on a recent contract are an interesting study:

Three-coat work of Paripan was called for on a small job on a hospital. The lowest tender was $975. As the trustees did not wish to go to this expense they called for three coats of good oil enamel paint. The lowest tender was $890. Taking the life of paint as 7 years and Paripan as at least 14 years, the paint bill on the above figures would be for 14 years as follows:

Paint, $1,780; Paripan, $975.

Note.—Not only would the saving be large, but during the 14 years there would be a washable surface; the place would be cleanly and the appearance would be all that could be desired.

SUGGESTION FOR DECORATING YOUR HOUSE WITH PARIPAN PROCESS

Remember that bright and cheerful paint work adds 50 per cent. to the home. You cannot get light-colored paint in the ordinary way that will wash down. Specify and see you get Paripan Glossy or Flat; they will wash and wear for an indefinite time and retain their color.

INTERIOR.

BEDROOMS.—Woodwork in Glossy, white or cream; plaster walls in Flat tint to suit furniture, etc.

BATHROOMS AND KITCHENS.—Woodwork in Glossy, white, cream or grey; walls and ceiling in light shade of blue or green.

RECEPTION, DRAWING ROOMS AND HALLS.—Panels of deep Flat color, filling in with very light Flat tints to match woodwork in Flat or Glossy.

EXTERIOR.

WOODWORK.—Finished entirely with the Glossy light colors and trim of a deep color.
WHERE AND HOW TO USE "PARIPAN"

Paripan is recommended for all classes of work. It is used on wood, metal of all kinds, plaster and stone, inside or outside.

Specifications will be furnished for treating any work on request, but the following may be taken as a basis:

For interior plaster, ceilings, doors and woodwork, metal, or any new surface—Two coats of Paripan Filler or undercoat (the second coat tinted with some of the Glossy or Flat color) if colors are to be used for final coat; then one or two coats of Glossy or Flat Paripan, according to finish desired. The Filler or undercoat is given to prepare a good base for the finish—a glance will tell you if another coat is needed. Naturally the better the base the better the finish.

For Old Surfaces—One or two coats of either Glossy or Dull. This must depend on the condition of surface to be treated and if the same color is to be applied again. If a light color is to be applied to an old dark color, then base of ordinary filler, mixed with a little of the finishing color (Glossy or Flat) should be applied before putting on Glossy or Dull.

For exterior work, new metal or wood—Two coats Paripan Filler and two coats of Glossy Paripan.

Stropping.—This should be done with Paripan Filler, softened if necessary, with a little dry white lead. Putty should not be used on any account.

Plaster walls and ceilings must be perfectly dry and clean before any paint is put on, or the free lime and moisture will change the color and cause the material to flake off. If necessary to treat before plaster is in proper condition, give one or two coats of Paripan Filler tinted. This treatment is more satisfactory than distempering, as the Filler will do for many years when the wall is to be finished with Paripan Glossy or Flat.

BIG BEN, Houses of Parliament, London, England—one of England's most famous landmarks—is treated with Paripan. The photograph shows the clock face being painted. Note the size of the men.
A FEW HINTS WHEN PARIPANNING.

Open tin as per instructions on tin.
Stir thoroughly; remove skin, if any; be careful to get no loose hairs on work; give 24 hours between each coat (except the second which should be applied final coat (it may be necessary to rub surface down to obtain this).
Do not put on a thick coat: work it out well on surface when applying. The result is worth the extra care.
Use a clean, dry, brush or bristle paint roller. On a short or semi-gloss surface, add a small proportion of Glossy to Paripan Flat. See that the surface on which you intend putting Paripan is thoroughly clean. All grease and dirt must be removed and see that no dust is around.

WASHING PARIPAN

Only cold water and sponge. If surface is very greasy use a little soap. Do not scrape washing lightly.
Dry the glossy surface with a soft cloth and polish with a dust-free leather to increase gloss. The Flat should be dried with a dabbing motion, not by rubbing forwards and backwards, as this creates gloss.

On any points that may arise, please write us and we will give you full information.

Note the reflection of light on this corridor in the Bournemouth Royal Victoria Hospital in England.

Paripan was used because it can be washed down indefinitely with soap and water. "The more you wash it the better it looks."

A FEW FACTS ABOUT PARIPAN.

There are 16 acres of Paripanned walls in the London Hospital, England.

The English Navy gave one order for Paripan amounting to 5,643 gallons.

Dr. Eyre, of Guy's Hospital, London, Eng., states by personal experience that Paripanned surface bacteria can be removed owing to the polish and evenness of the surface.

Verandahs and outside woodwork when treated with Paripan can be washed down and should not require recoating for 7 to 10 years.

Paripan has been used on some of the finest Canadian homes, clubs and public buildings.

Paripan was one of the first enamels made in England over 40 years ago.

Paripan is used on railway coaches, motor cars, yachts, etc.

COVERING CAPACITY

PARIPAN GLOSSY.—1 gallon covers 810 square feet.

PARIPAN FLAT.—16 lbs. cover 810 square feet.

PARIPAN FILLER (or Undercoating).—16 lbs. cover 810 square feet.

These covering capacities may be relied upon.

Glossy is supplied in ½, ¼, ½ and 1-gal. cans, in various colors, ready for use. Note the wonderful covering capacity. It dries from the base upwards, is absolutely waterproof, tough and elastic, besides being so brilliant that it has a surface like glass. It is improved by washing, and in fact "the more you wash it the better it looks."

Paripan Flat is supplied in various packages, 8 and 16-lb. tins, ready for use. This is a beautiful material, equally washable as the Glossy. It has a beautiful dull sheen which is particularly fine. The use of our Flat Paripan avoids the old method of rubbing down the Glossy to obtain a Flat finish.

Paripan Filler, or undercoating, is supplied in 7, 14 and 100-lb. packages. It is recommended to use this exclusively under Paripan Glossy or Flat, as it forms a hard, non-absorbent base and throws the finishing coat out well. It is also recommended to use Paripan Filler in place of white lead for general purposes, as it is a better obscurer and goes much further. For the sake of comparison, 9 lbs. of Filler are generally reckoned to be equal to a gallon of white lead and oil paint.

C.V.C. CLEANER AND POLISHER.—If you have a good piece of furniture so dirty that you cannot see the finish—dirty paint or varnish work—put some C.V.C. on a flannel and rub it gently; it will remove the dirt and marks etc. When dirt is removed, rub lightly with a soft rag and it will bring up the finish and add to the lustre.

If you polish your floors, your furniture, your paintwork, etc., with C.V.C., you will keep it clean, and at the same time improve the finish you have on it.
PREVENTION OF THE SPREAD OF DISEASE THROUGH WALL CONTAMINATION FROM BREATH

Vide "The Times" Report (August 14th, 1906) of Dr. Murray Gordon's investigation into impurities of the atmosphere of the House of Commons, and Report to Local Government Board, 1902-3, re investigation in Schoolrooms.

PARIPAN: THE REMEDY
CHEAP, EFFICIENT, PERMANENT

THE Government Investigations as to the spread of disease, such as epidemics of diphtheria in schools, and of influenza in the House of Commons, have proved that the cause is attributable to bacterially-contaminated moisture, projected from the mouth when speaking.

Experiments show that persons infected with, or convalescent from contagious infectious diseases, and carrying bacilli in the mucus membrane of the mouth and throat, can infect others at a distance of 40 feet! A specially prepared plate having been placed upon the Cabinet Minister's box in the House of Commons, a speaker's throat was inoculated with a special, but harmless and easily recognized bacillus (B. prodigious); subsequent examination proving that no less than 83 colonies of this particular bacillus had been formed upon the prepared test-plate, and this from the mouth and throat of one speaker only!

HOSPITALS, SCHOOLS, BARRACKS, WORKHOUSES

A heavy responsibility is therefore shown to rest on those in control of buildings where numbers of human beings congregate, to employ a material upon the walls and ceilings which will permit of their being easily and frequently freed from infectious deposits arising from condensation of breath, or projection of particles.

"Prevention is better than cure," and for such purposes Paripan is better than any Paint or varnish.

If the act of speaking by one person in a great chamber such as the House of Commons can cause 83 colonies of bacilli to be formed upon a small plate within it, how great must be the possible area of contamination in a room or ward say of 60 ft. x 40 ft. x 20 ft. (the walls and ceiling of which would have a surface of some 6,400 square feet!) when occupied by a large number of persons.

If these walls be finished with Paripan the cost of keeping them clean and free from infection is but very small, and can be constantly repeated. With ordinary paints and enamels such an operation would destroy their appearance, and owing to their rough surfaces (see diagram on page 3), but small benefit would be derived.

The reverse is the case with Paripan, for "the more it is washed the better it looks."

July 23rd 1904

Messrs Randall Bros.,

Gentlemen,

In accordance with your request I have carried out a series of experiments on ("Glassy") Paripan, and from the results obtained conclude that the preparation is an excellent one for the purpose you suggest viz., to replace glazed tiles, distemper and paint on the walls and ceilings of hospital wards, on the grounds of efficiency no less than economy.

The surface of Paripan is of a high polish, even and continuous, appearing almost perfectly smooth under the highest power of microscope, and moreover it is easily and thoroughly cleaned. Emulsions of pathogenic microbes including those of plague, cholera, typhoid, diphtheria etc., were applied on the paripanised surfaces of plates, tables etc., and there allowed to dry. It was subsequently found that owing to the polish and evenness of the surface, nearly all the bacteria could be removed by vigorously rubbing the infected area with cotton wool in a primitive manner, thus killing all the infecting microorganisms. As the surface of Paripan is unaffected by the disinfectants in ordinary use (carbolic acid, 5% lysol, 4% mercuric perchloride) it is possible to remove the deposit of paripan from surfaces from which some can be removed although the preparation after its application to walls etc., can be in no way regarded as an active antiseptic. (Note: In this connection it should be observed that Alcohol or hydrochloric acid concentrations will destroy the high polish of even surface of Paripan).

Paripan is extensively used here in Guy's Hospital and its durability is evidenced by the present condition of the walls of one of our isolation wards, which were coated with this preparation upwards of six years ago.

I am, Gentlemen,

I beg to report to you re Ryerson New School House basement.

I did not grant the final certificate last fall as I was suspicious of concrete wall keeping out the water in the spring. I have asked the contractor several times to get it fixed up but he wants to plaster on the inside.

I have told him the only remedy is to dig a 2 ft. trench around the rear wall to the bottom of cement work and plaster up with good cement on outside of wall and leave trench open until thoroughly dry before refilling.

The water is oozing through the rear wall for three feet up and around the cement steps leading to basement in rear. Otherwise the building is in good shape.

I am Your Obedient Servant,

Sir,

I beg to report to you that the well is about 300 yards from the school. It is very hard to estimate what a well would cost as the school is quite high above the lake and unless we happened to strike a spring we might have to go very deep. I would think a fair estimate would be $75.00. The present well is first class spring water and the distance of 300 yards is not very far but I think it might be boxed in and a pump put in. I would like to get authority to level off school grounds and fence in same. Put two cement walks into the school from road and one to teachers house, total cost probably $125.00.

I beg to make further report re well at Ryerson School, Parry Island and may say that I have gone into the matter with D.L. King, school caretaker, who is the only Indian there who can be depended upon to do any work of this kind and think the most suitable and likely place to get water is about seventy-five yards in front of school house. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant furnishing a report as to the cost of providing a well at the Ryerson Indian Day School, Parry Island.

In reply I beg to say that, if you consider that this work could be satisfactorily performed and a good supply of water obtained, you may arrange to have the work done, including the cost of the labour in digging the well to a sufficient depth to obtain a good supply of water and furnishing a pump. The Department could not approve of any expenditure for the purpose in excess of approximately $75.00 to $90.00. It is understood that an exact estimate of the cost of digging the well cannot be given, as this will depend upon the depth required to be excavated. You should see that the work is properly performed and stoned up with a platform on top and that the pump is properly installed. The Department will leave this matter in your hands and you should arrange to have the work done as cheaply as possible. You should give this matter your prompt attention, in order that the work can be done before the winter season.

As soon as the work is completed you should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the labour and also the cost of the pump. In purchasing the pump competitive prices should be obtained and you should purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 9th instant, embodying a resolution passed at a regular meeting of the Parry Island Band on the 3rd instant authorizing the purchase from band funds of an organ for the use of the Ryerson Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that it is doubtful whether this organ would be of any permanent use. While the present teacher may be able to utilize the organ, another teacher might not be able to use it. As this is a second-hand organ, it is considered that the price asked, viz: $40, is greatly in excess of that for which an organ of this type can be obtained. Unless the present owner is prepared to dispose of the organ at a much reduced price, the Department is not prepared to authorize its purchase.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am writing to inform you that the Spence Indian Day School is badly in need of repair inside and outside. The plaster is peeling off and the walls and ceiling require a thorough clean-up.

I have discussed the matter with the local Indian agent and he tells me that he could put the house in good shape for approximately $150.00. This is too nice a school to be allowed to fall into disrepair. I would also like to have about 20 tons of gravel put down in front of the schoolhouse to prevent mud from being tracked into the school. The total transaction including the gravel should not exceed $175.00. I shall recommend that this allow be made in the budget.

Trusting that this will meet with your approval,

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, March 13th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, relative to the repairs required to the plaster, walls and ceiling of the Ryerson Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $100 in having the interior of this building repaired and painted and placed in good condition. You may arrange with a local painter to do the work during the summer vacation.

We will also approve of having approximately 20 loads of gravel put down in front of the schoolhouse, in order to level up the entrance to the building and make it dry.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expense of the above authorized work. The account should show the cost of any material, such as paint, etc., separately from the amount charged for the labour. A separate voucher should also be forwarded for the expenditure incurred in supplying the gravel and spreading it in front of the school building. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have the work completed when considered timely by you. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and the total expenditure for the painting and cleaning of the school building and the supplying of the gravel should not exceed your estimate of approximately $125.00.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, December 4th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, enclosing accounts in payment for the work performed on the well at the Ryerson Indian Day School. Cheques in payment of these accounts have been sent. We note that this well is of no use, as no water can be obtained from it.

Relative to your request for authority to dig a new well near the shore of the lake, I shall be pleased if you will state approximately the cost of this work, also whether you would advise that the well be dug at the present time, or whether it would be advisable to wait until next Spring. Please also state what arrangements you can make for the labour, or how you purpose having the work done.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
Replying to yours of the 4th inst., 22-3-5, I have to report that I have gone over the ground for the proposed well very carefully along with the Indian in charge of repairs on the dock at Parry Island. It is expected that we will encounter quicksand in digging the well and it is thought that the best time to dig would be as soon as work on the dock is completed. To make a job worth while and a credit to the Dept., it will take three men between three and five days to complete the well.

What I purpose doing is to dig deep enough so that the well will not go dry even should the lake drop other four feet, crib with with stone, there is plenty of rock handy, and put the pump in. In the Spring of the year, put a cement coping over the well to keep out surface water. To fix it up for immediate use, the cost would be the labour of three men for five days at three dollars making a total of forty-five dollars, if possible, and it is possible that the work might be done in three days.

I will endeavour to have it done as cheaply as possible.

Trusting that this will be satisfactory,

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

J.D. McLean Esq.,
Secretary Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, December 11, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, stating the approximate cost of having a well dug at the Ryerson Indian Day School, and also how you propose having the work carried out.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have the work in digging this well carried out at a time considered by you most advantageous to do so. We note that it will take 3 men from 3 to 5 days to complete the work. If a pump is required, you may arrange for the purchase of same.

When the work has been completed, please forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, for the amount due for the labour employed and for any other expenses incurred. Please endeavour to keep the total cost of the work down to the lowest possible point.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Sir:

I have to report that the basement of the Ryerson Indian Day School, Parry Island, is flooded by water. I was advised on Sunday that the drain was stopped and the water was rising. I gave instructions to the caretaker, Mathew King, to get the poles and wires his father, the late D. L. King, had for the purpose of clearing the drain. Mathew has been working at it off and on since Sunday. I have made an inspection as far as possible and have come to the conclusion that, as the same thing happened last spring, the drain should be opened up and cement-jointed, also the connection from the rain pipes should be cemented, that is where the rain pipe enters the tile. This, I think is the cause of the trouble, as these connections have been open and the possibility is that some rubbish has slipped down this part of the drain. There are three of such connections. Yesterday and today, there was a pungent odour in the school and as the water is up to the furnace door, no fire could be put in the furnace, accordingly, there is no school being held.

Please instruct if I can go ahead and open up the drain and have the tile fixed with cement at all the connections, as soon as possible. If the weather keeps mild, school will be held tomorrow. I am leaving on the 2:55 A.M. for Gibson to meet Mr. McGloon and may be away for a day or two. Should you wire instructions to repair the drain, my stenographer will attend to the matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir:
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

JMD/RD

Sir:

I have to report that while visiting Ryerson Indian Bay School, at Parry Island and inspecting the buildings, on complaint of Miss McFarland, the teacher, I examined the upstairs and found that the roof has been leaking at the chimney.

The flashing requires to be looked after, and a few shingles put on. This is not to be wondered at, owing to the terrific windstorms we have been having recently. The steps approaching the school are in need of repair, and the doors will have to be rehung, as they are catching.

It appears to me that the centre foundation, which is also the foundation of the chimney, seems to have settled somewhat. This defect is now being shown in the school by the plaster being cracked on both sides of the chimney. This cracking does not hurt in any way, except to the appearance, but the doors, flashing, shingles, and the steps approaching the school will have to be looked after right away.

Your early consideration would be appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Ottawa, September 24, 1929.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Parry Sound Agency.

Parry Island school is in very fair condition. The plaster on the inside walls is broken off in places. This should be repaired and the interior painted next summer. The closets are very dirty inside. The front screens have been destroyed. These should be replaced and both closets painted. This might possibly wait until next summer, but the screens should be attended to as soon as possible. Three broken window lights should be replaced.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.
Ottawa, September 28, 1929.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited your agency, reports that the plaster on the inside walls of the Ryerson Indian Day School is broken off in places; that the closets are very dirty inside; the front screens have been destroyed and that three broken window lights require to be replaced. I have to request that you will arrange to have the repairs mentioned by the Inspector carried out. You should also see that the closets are thoroughly cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition before the extreme cold weather sets in, and the repairs to the screens should be attended to as soon as possible.

The Inspector also recommends that both closets be painted, but states that this might possibly wait over until next summer. Please state whether you would recommend that the closets be painted at the present time and the approximate cost of same, or whether you would recommend that this work be left over until next summer.

Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the carrying out of the above mentioned repairs.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir;

While on a visit of inspection to Ryerson Indian Day School Parry Island, yesterday, in the course of conversation with Mr. Bolton, the teacher there, he informed me that he had received the charts and cards but on checking up he finds that he has not received six Beacon Gate to Reading, Six Beacon Primers, and teacher's Manual.

He seems to be fitting in all right and is anxious to receive these books. Your consideration in this matter will be greatly appreciated.

I have to state that on examining the back door platform, that in my endeavour to keep down expenses of repairs I had mentioned that we would put in a wooden gutter to carry the water off the back door platform. I find that this will not do, and that it will be necessary for me to put a covering over the platform in the form of a porch. I found on looking around that there was one bundle of shingles and what would be required would be about 150 feet of one inch lumber, tongue and groove, and five pieces of scantling, 2 x 4 dressed. This, I think, would be the cheapest way of getting this thing fixed up for a number of years.

I would appreciate it very much if you would grant the requisition for this.
I presume there is no use in asking for the interior of the teacher's house to be calsoined just now. It has been some time since this was done. If it is at all possible I would like to have it done between this and Christmas. If there is not sufficient funds we will have to let the matter ride until next March.

I have had a letter from Miss Emily Donald. She seems to be fitting in all right at Moose Point, and had 12 in attendance on the first day.

I met Mrs. Munson and child and Miss O'Meara and went with them north. I could not go with Miss O'Meara to the school as I had to go on to Lower French with Mrs. Munson. There is a requisition for School Material in this mail to you, for Mrs. Munson's School, Lower French, and I would be very grateful if you would pass this requisition as soon as possible. All the things mentioned are absolutely necessary, except the shelving for books. There was shelving for books made in the form of a shelf, which was not there when I looked around the place, nor mentioned in the inventory left by the teacher. I will make enquiries about this in the near future and find out what has become of it.

I am a little up against it today, not feeling very good, but expect to be able to get around and make a trip up north to see Miss O'Meara, when I shall also go to Lower French and make enquiries about this shelf. I would like to state that I believe Mrs. Munson will fit in at Lower French all right. She appeared to make a good impression on the members of the Band who were at the station and with the white people whom she came in contact with.

I should also state that the seats in the boat and the knees for same have to be fixed up, and I gave instructions to the caretaker to go ahead and make the best job possible. You will remember, Mr. Ferrier, this boat was second hand when it was bought.
We will try to make it do this season, but I am very much afraid that we will have to get another boat for next spring, but if possible I will try and make it do for another year.

Mrs. Munson seems will pleased with her school.

With kind regards to the staff, and you and yours.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

MD/EM
Ottawa, September 11, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, reporting on your visit of inspection to the Ryerson Indian Day School.

Regarding the 6 Beacon Gate to Reading, 6 Beacon Primers and Teacher's Manual which the teacher informed you he had not received, I have to say that it was necessary to obtain these texts from the publishers in New York, and it is hoped that Mr. Bolton will receive them at an early date.

Regarding your recommendation as to the best means of carrying the water off the back door platform, the Department will approve of you arranging to put a cover, in the form of a porch, over the platform, and you may purchase the lumber, etc., required, in having this work carried out. Please keep all expense as low as possible, and forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the materials and for any labour employed.

The Department has no funds to provide for the kalsomining of the interior of the teacher's house at the present time.

You will be written in a separate communication regarding the furnishing of the supplies asked for by Mrs. Munson, teacher of the Lower French River Indian Day School.

It is noted that you have authorized the caretaker to make sufficient repairs to the boat at the Mazanetawan School to place it in serviceable condition during the present season.

The Department is pleased to note that the teachers who have been engaged this year for the schools in your Agency appear satisfactory to you. It is hoped that they will all meet with success during the present academic year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

Enclosed please find requisition for school material and supplies for the teacher's house at the Ryerson Indian Day School.

I have marked the sheets 1, 2, and 3.

You will observe that on No. 2 sheet I have marked "Dont approve, never had any," and don't want to start! and have put my initials to it. That is the request for wash basins and washstands, pails for water, drinking cups, towels, soap and requisition sheets. It seems to me silly for Mr. Bolton to put on his requisition sheet, "Requisition Sheets." I did not notice it when he was here last night or I would have drawn his attention to it. He can get all the requisition sheets he requires here.

The children of this school are not the same as in the other outlying Reserves and should be made to wash at home. The drinking cups and pails, I do not think are necessary. When Miss Smiley was in this school, to keep down scabby mouths she had them bring their own drinking vessels and in many cases provided glass pickle jars for this purpose. The reason for this order, is because of an article in the local paper written by the Missionary preacher on Parry Island, about the well ordered arrangement at Moose Deer Point School regarding the washing and teeth drill, that is practised there.
Moose Deer Point School is out of the way and is necessary to insist on this as the mothers are not so up to date as the mothers on Parry Island. In any case I don't approve of this request being granted as I think it is just a fad on the part of the teacher.

No. 1. Sheet I have marked "Seats for rear desks" and have initialed same. This means that the rear desks of the school require to be used but there are no seats for them. This is a good thing to have. I have told the teacher that I have been trying to keep down expenses and to get along as best he can until after March, however he has put it in his requisition and as it is necessary for the school, I have put in my remarks so the Department will understand what is meant.

On Sheet No. 1, the items "Kindergarten tables and chairs" I don't approve of. I have signed my initials to same. I think there is a lot of unnecessary fluff attached to the kindergarten work that the children are getting here. I don't think it is necessary to go to the expense of getting tables and chairs. I certainly don't approve of it under the present circumstances. I would like to get a little progress in the three R's in this school more than anything else.

I am very much of the opinion of the Inspector Mr. Moore, I don't know what his report was but I agree with him whatever it is, after conversation I had with him.

For the information of the Department I might say that Mr. Bolton has kindly consented to fill in and take the service of the Anglican Church at Depot Harbour, on Sundays, which is about three miles from where he is. I am pleased with him doing this,
but being cursed or blessed with an insight into human nature I am afraid it will be a case of swelled head for Mr. Bolton. I am satisfied it is only a passing phase as I know the people in this district very well, and you can do anything you like coming into this district, until after you are tried out, then you are allowed to wither and die if you are that kind.

Trusting this will give the Department an idea just how the case stands regarding this requisition.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

JMD, EK.

Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Ryerson Indian Day School for classroom supplies and supplies for the use of the school and residence. I have noted your remarks regarding several of the requests made by the teacher. A requisition is being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the classroom supplies considered necessary.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- 50 Lbs. sweeping compound
- 1 Broom
- 2 Sauce pans
- 6 Cups and saucers
- 6 Tumblers
- 1 Water dipper
- 1 Blind, Green, 56" x 26"
- 10 Lbs. chloride lime for toilets

After the above purchases have been made, you should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Department is not prepared to supply the kindergarten tables and chairs, wash basins and stands, drinking cups and towels.

Regarding the 5 rear seats asked for, I have to say that the Department is of opinion that the desks at present in use were purchased from the E. N. Moyer Co., Ltd., Toronto, in 1915. If the desks were obtained from that firm, they will likely bear the stamp of the manufacturer - W. F. Vilas Company. You should ascertain the size of the desks for which the rear seats are required, and you may place an order with the E. N. Moyer Company, Toronto, for the 5 extra rear seats required. You should furnish them with full shipping directions and request them to forward you their account, in duplicate, covering the cost F.O.B. point of delivery. After this equipment is received, if in good condition, you should certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Parry Sound, Ont.
June 24, 1932.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.
Supt. Indian Education Canada,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

This is to thank you for sending the teachers' cheques. I received them all except Mrs. English's and have been wondering if it is possible that this cheque might have gone to some other agency. I do know that Mrs. English needs her cheque in the worst way, and if it has not been sent out, I would appreciate it very much if you would send it along as soon as possible.

I was examining the well at Parry Island and am sorry to state but it is true, we will require to have some lumber to build a covering over the well, a little building 6 x 6 x 7, of rough lumber, and which should not cost any more, for materials, building and transportation, than $15.00. They have tried having this well left open but it is no good, the Indians come and use it, and the result is that it is liable to be broken.

I have to get planking eight pieces 2 x 8 for the platform, and thought when we had to get that we might just as well get more rough boards and 2 x 4's and put a cover on the well. A padlock will also be required to keep the well under lock and key for the teacher's use. I would be very glad if I could have this done and I will guarantee it will be done as cheap as anywhere in Canada.

Please let me know about this, Mr. Ferrier, as soon as you can, as we have the pump now and I am anxious to have this thing fixed up.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I have to report that the cellar of the teachers' house in the Ryerson Indian Day School is flooded. This drain has been giving a lot of trouble. I am afraid it will have to be taken up the whole way across the road to the outlet, and perhaps some new pipe put in.

Mr. Solton, the school master informs me that there is about six or seven inches of water in the cellar now. This is very unhealthy for the teacher and his family, and for the school too, and I would like to have the authority of the Department to go ahead and have it fixed up before the frosty weather comes on.

The consideration of the Department at their very earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Ottawa, May 10th, 1933.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I inspected the Parry Sound Agency on the 25th-26th ultimo and beg to submit the following report.

The Ryerson School will need a new furnace next winter. The one in use at present was installed in 1915 and is burned out past repair. The building is very badly in need of paint. This should be done as soon as possible otherwise it will deteriorate rapidly. The interior of the residence and classroom also needs painting. The front steps of the residence are badly worn and should be replaced.

Thos. H. Cookin.
Inspector.
Ottawa, May 19, 1933.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Parry Sound Agency, states that a new furnace is required for next winter's use in the Ryerson Indian Day School, as the present one is burned out and past repair. He also recommends that the school building be painted, both inside and outside.

I would request that, in due time, you furnish an estimate of the cost of installing a new furnace of a type considered satisfactory by you to properly heat the building. I may add that, as our Appropriation this year has been so considerably reduced, we will have no funds to carry out the painting or redecorating required at any of the Indian day schools this year.

The Inspector also states that the front steps of the residence are badly worn and should be repaired. I would request that you give an estimate of the cost of repairing or replacing these steps.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

J. M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Re the steps of the schoolhouse that is just a matter of the material and the time which will not exceed $10.00. As the carpenter is not doing very much just now, I would suggest that the Department give permission for this work to be done right away.

Sir,

Replying to yours of May 19th, 22-3-5, and following mine of May 23rd, T-5164, re estimate of cost of instalment of a furnace in the Hyerson Indian Day School, Parry Island Reserve, enclosed please find an estimate by Mr. T. H. Marwood.

I would recommend that Mr. Marwood get consideration as the furnaces that he has installed in the past have given every satisfaction.

Sir;

Replying to yours of August 30th,
A-8-5 re installing of furnace in the Ryerson
Indian Day school, enclosed please find account
with copy of the contract.

When writing to the Department about
this furnace I sent the contract to the Department,
and as Mr. Marwood was away from home doing some work,
I could not get the copy of the contract sooner.

I have been to the Ryerson Indian Day
School and examined this furnace and everything seems
to be in first class shape. I had Mr. Marwood
put a fire on and went over the radiators in the
school and teacher's house, and find that the new
furnace sends up heat very much more quickly than
the old one did.

I examined the old furnace. It is all
cracked and broken up, and it is scrap. I do not know
of any person who is buying scrap around here at the
present time, but owing to it being on the Island
it is going to be a hard job to turn the scrap
into money, but if possible I will do so.
There are about 1300 bricks or parts of bricks.
These bricks are cement ones and in the taking down
of the furnace they were pretty nearly all broken
in two, and the lime adheres to the bricks that were
not broken, and it is going to be a pretty hard
job to make a sale of them.
In the meantime, I have them piled at the back of the teacher's house and if it is possible to make a sale of them I shall do so. So far as I can see it is all scrap but if it is possible to turn it into money I shall do so, and whatever I get for it I shall send to the Department.

I trust that a cheque will be sent forward to Mr. Marwood as soon as possible. Mr. Marwood has taken over the Plumbing and Heating business of Wm. Beatty Company here, and would appreciate it if you would send on the cheque as soon as possible.

I consider this is a very good job. All the work that Mr. Marwood has done for the Department has been satisfactory. He installed the furnaces in the Shawanaga Hall and in the Teacher's house at the Lower French Indian Day School.

The consideration of the Department at their earliest will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

Following mine of April 11th, T-5524 re the obstruction in the drain from the teacher's house at the Ryerson Indian Day School, Stephen Partridge whom I have had looking the situation over informs me that the pipes are a solid block of ice and it may take some time before they will thaw out. I do not think it advisable to open up the drain as I think in the natural course of events the ice will thaw sufficient in the pipes to let the water get away. The weather is moderating somewhat.

In the meantime I have instructed the teacher to hold school in the hall where the children are quite comfortable. If it is the wish of the Department that I should open up the drain and have the ice knocked out of the pipes I shall do so, but I do not think this will be necessary as it will thaw sufficient in a day or so to allow the accumulated water in the cellar to get away.

I am very much puzzled about the way this drain has been stopped up under the present occupants of the school. It never gave any trouble before. I think it would be an expense to open up the drain and the possibilities are that
they might smash some of the pipes trying to get the ice out.

I have had Stephen Partridge working on this for one day, but will not send in his bill for the work until I have word from the Department that they approve of my actions in this matter.

Sir:

Replying to yours of April 23rd, 22-3-5, re the painting of the school buildings and teachers houses at Ryerson, Shawanaga, and Lower French Indian Day schools, I have visited the reserves recently and following are the conclusions I have come to:

The Lower French School and teacher's residence can get along nicely with nothing done to the interior but they are badly in need of painting outside. I think it would be arranged to have some of the Indians paint the buildings on the outside at Lower French. I have not much faith in the Indians painting as they make it patchy, but there are one or two white people there that I could get to do this satisfactorily. The Department could pay the paint and pay them by the wages for the job, holding them down to a certain number of days.

As to the Ryerson school, it will be necessary to do some plastering, calsoining, and painting of the ceiling of the school, calsoining and painting of the doors and wainscoting in the interior of the house.

In the Shawanaga Teacher's house, the plaster is in very bad shape. Where there are only a few places that are broken there is quite a lot of the ceiling and walls cracked and when the plastering would start it might turn out to be a big job, that is, where the workmen would start out to do one yard of plastering it might turn out to be ten yards.

The man doing the plastering could do the calsoining. There is some work to be done on the verandah of the teachers house at Shawanaga. I have a requisition for this, but was leaving the whole job to be done at the one time.
The tradesman doing the Ryerson teacher's house could do the Shawanaga teacher's house, too.

If the Department approves of my suggestions I will get a tradesman to look over the work. I think I can get it done at a reasonable price at the present time as the men are in need of work. It would not be advisable to get Indian labour to do this work as they do not know anything about plastering and would only make a mess of the job.

Trusting this will be satisfactory to the Department.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Ottawa, June 10, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, stating the approximate length of time that would be required to carry out the plastering, kalsomining and interior painting necessary at the Ryerson and Shawanaga Indian Day Schools.

December 11, 1935,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario,

Sir,

I have to report that the roof of the school building of the Ayerson Indian Day School is leaking. I had a carpenter go up the other day and examine this. He informed me that the zinc gutter requires to be renewed. The frame work of the bell tower has also to be renewed. The water is coming down into the school and streaking the wall.

The weather is suitable at the present time to get this thing done as there is no snow on the roof. It will require about 36 feet of zinc for both the gutters, 2 bundles of shingles, and about 50 feet of hardwood for the frame of the bell. The labour will cost more than the material as it is one of these jobs where you have to tear up and replace.

This thing has to be done right away.

The exact cost I cannot state, but I can assure the Department that everything will be done at the lowest possible price.

Please reply by return mail if I can go ahead and have this work done.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

JMD/EK.

Agent.
Ottawa, December 14, 1935.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant, you may make the necessary repairs to the Ryerson Indian Day School. The Department will depend on you to keep the cost as low as possible.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir:

I have to report that in an interview with A. G. Slaght, K.C., M.P. for Parry Sound District, he talked to me about the painting of the Shawanaga Indian Day School and in the course of conversation I explained to him that there are two other schools to paint, one Parry Island and the other Lower French.

We talked of Widow Wm. Fritsche, who has a man by the name of Nurnberg employed to do the painting, and I explained to Mr. Slaght that Nurnberg had painted my house and made a good job of it and I was sure that he would make a first class job of the school at the price quoted. Mr. Slaght asked me if it was satisfactory for me to have Mrs. Fritsche get the contract with Nurnberg to do the work for her, and I told him that I was satisfied that we would get a better job done on the schools than has ever been done before. He advised me to go ahead and get the work done as the weather is suitable.

I might explain to the Department that this is the first time I have ever been interviewed by the member for the District in connection with work, and I would appreciate it very much if the Department will advise me that Mrs. Wm. Fritsche can have the contracts for the schools as follows:

- Parry Island - $200.00
- Lower French - $230.00
- Shawanaga - $230.00

I am perfectly satisfied that I can get a good job done.
for this money. I should state that these schools have been long overdue for painting and I am anxious to see that the best possible job will be done on a two coat job.

I would appreciate it very much if the Department would say if I can go ahead and get the painting done.

There is a lot of painting being done in this section of the country at the present time and as one of these schools is out of the way I would like to have them all done by the end of August, if possible.

The consideration of the Department in this matter by return mail, if possible, will be very much appreciated.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) John M. Daly,
Agent.

JMD/EK.
Ottawa, July 16, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, regarding the painting of three Indian Day Schools in the Parry Sound agency, viz.: Shawanaga, Lower French River and Ryerson (Parry Island).

You were written yesterday, regarding the painting of the exterior of the Shawanaga Indian Day School and teacher's residence.

The Department will approve of you making the same arrangements for the purchase of materials and for the carrying out of the work at the Lower French and Parry Island Schools as in the case at Shawanaga. You should arrange for the purchase of the materials, paints, oils, etc., from the McKinley Hardware Company, Parry Sound, or other firms on the approved list, and the work can be performed by Mr. Nurnberg, in the employ of Mr. Wm. Fritsche. It is understood that Indian labour will be utilized to assist Mr. F. Nurnberg in carrying out the work.

I may say that the funds provided for the painting at each of these schools are as follows:

Shawanaga - $230.00
Lower French - $230.00
Ryerson (Parry Island) - $200.00

The total cost of material and labour at each school should not exceed the amount provided. After all work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the paint, etc., and returns, in triplicate, for the labour. The number of days or hours employed and the rate paid should be definitely stated.

It is noted that the Federal member for the constituency approves of the work being carried out as stated above. The matter of colours of paint and the work to be done for the funds provided will be left in your hands.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir;

Enclosed please find pay sheet for repairs done on the Ryerson School Parry Island reserve.

I have to state that in discussing the matter with Stephen Partridge re the condition of the roof, he is of the opinion that it will have to be reshingled in the very near future. I would therefore suggest to the Department that in their estimates for the coming year that they would allow for the shingling of the roof. The Department have the plans of the building there and would be able to estimate how many shingles it would take to do the building.

PARKY SOUND, ONTARIO,
July 16th, 1938.

THE SECRETARY,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Dear Sir:

Re your letter of June 23rd, file No. 22-35 granting permission for repairs to Ryerson Indian Day School.

I beg to report that I have examined the school and find that besides the repairs authorized in your letter the following work should be done. The main foundation wall, where the wall around the outside stairway abuts it, is broken 4' by 6'. In my opinion, it would be useless to fix the wall around the stairway without fixing the portion of the main wall which is broken.

I also find that the shingles are half off the roof of one lavatory, and that the steps leading to one of the school entrances, are in very bad condition. There are also three panes of glass out of the basement windows.

These three last items mentioned, would not cost very much. The main expense would be the cement work.

I would be glad if you would give this matter your consideration and advise me.

Thanking you, I am,

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I wish to advise you that there are two wells from which this school may get water and they both appear to be in bad condition.

Mr. Horne, the present teacher at Ryerson School has sent samples of water from both these wells to the Health Department at Toronto for analysis and they both have been rated "D", which I believe is very poor.

I am enclosing reports received by Mr. Horne and I wish you would give this matter your consideration and advise me what should be done.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo with reference to the water supply at the Ryerson Indian Day School.

In view of the report that has been received regarding the condition of the water the teacher should be instructed to boil all water used for drinking purposes. If it is necessary to purchase any special vessel in which to boil the water you may do so. At the present season of the year it is impossible to consider digging another well.

Have you made certain that there is no sewage that might be contaminating the water in the well? The reports which you forwarded are enclosed.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:— Re your letter of December 12th, file No. 22-3-5.

I am enclosing a clipping of a stove which I think would be suitable for Ryerson Indian Day School. This is a wood stove with four large holes and two small ones. It burns eighteen inch wood and has a reservoir attached.

I am also enclosing a letter from McKinley's Hardware in which they submit the price of $55.00 for this type of stove installed in Parry Island School.

Mr. McKinley assures me that this is an exceptionally good price and if you care for me to purchase it locally, here in Parry Sound, I will be glad to look after the matter for you.

Trusting this will be satisfactory, I am,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:-

As you know, we recently purchased a new cook stove for Ryerson Indian Day School, and I have had the old one stored in the basement.

I wish you would give me permission to sell this old stove for the best price I can. It is of no use to us, and although it is not of much value, I think I could dispose of it and thus get it out of the way.

Trusting to hear from you, I am,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re: Vouchers Nos. 765 and 769 enclosed.

I have been obliged to exceed the amount authorized for expenditure for the purpose of digging a well for the Parry Island school. My original intention had been to repair an old well near the school which had caved in, but I found this to be impracticable and decided to dig a new well in a better situation. July 10th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I am enclosing estimates of repairs necessary to the various schools in this Agency. Some of these estimates may appear high but the fact is that various repairs which were put off during the war years have accumulated.

The largest amount is for the Gibson Day School, the bulk of which is for fencing the school grounds and the erection of two new toilets. Authority was granted last year for these toilets to the amount of $112.00. I was unable to proceed with the work last year due to both the shortage of material and labour. I propose, if possible, to have it done this summer but a review of the situation shows the costs to be considerably increased due to prices of both material and labour.

I would be glad to have these costs for the various schools passed if at all possible but should it not be possible to pass on the amounts requested because of non-inclusion in the estimates, you might indicate what amounts would be available for expenditure on the various schools and I will have as much as possible completed this year and the balance next year. Your prompt attention to this will be appreciated as I would like to have the work completed during the summer holidays.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

Mr. S. Devlin, Supt. of Indian Agency,

Ryerson Indian Day School.

We regret that Mr. Sampson has not arrived as teacher at the above Indian Day School as arranged for. The Department concurs in your having Mrs. Perry re-assume her duties as teacher at this school. Mrs. Perry will receive the same rate of salary as that paid her previously, namely, $138.00 a teaching month.

It is our intention to include a sum for the erection of a new classroom at Ryerson in our next year's Main Estimates. Therefore, you can include the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of such a building in the estimates which you will be submitting shortly.

This will mean that the erection of the school should be begun in the Spring of 1949.

EXTRACT FROM A LETTER TO INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH FROM SAMUEL DEVLIN
INDIAN SUPT., PARRY SOUND AGENCY, DATED AUGUST 6, 1948.

Ryerson Day School
Repairs to kitchen drain

Materials $50.00
Labour 100.00 $150.00

(Sgd) Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.

Copied: V.S.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I am enclosing statement of repairs necessary for the various schools in this Agency.

The school on the Gibson Reserve had not been painted on the outside for a number of years and this job can now be done.

At the school at Shawanaga considerable damage had been done recently to the windows, as per my letter of July 20, and it will be necessary for me to send a glazier from Parry Sound to repair the damage. Hardwood flooring requires to be laid where the teacher's platform was taken out last year and the porch on the building needs considerable repair.

At the Lower French School the woodshed has collapsed and will require to be rebuild entirely. There is also some work to be done on the foundation of the school proper.

At the Ryerson School on Parry Island the kitchen drain has blocked up on various occasions with the result that the cellar has been flooded for lengthy periods. I believe that the drain will have to be dug up throughout its whole length and replaced.

If these expenditures are possible, I would be obliged if you would give me an accountable advance of $350.00 to pay for labour. Materials may all be purchased locally and the work will be done in all cases by Indian labour with the exception of the windows for the Shawanaga School.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) Samuel Devlin
Indian Superintendent.

Ryerson Indian Day School.

The Estimates for 1949/50 have now been approved by the Treasury Board and we are in a position to advise you that we have the sum of $14,000.00 to spend on the erection of a one-room school and attached teacher's residence at the above school. This is intended to be a new building, preferably in the same school yard, and would not be an addition to the present school.

Please find attached the following documents:

(a) Information Report to be completed by you on this project (three copies are to be filled, one for your files and two to be mailed here).

(b) A blueprint, plan 836.

We feel that this school will be quite satisfactory for your purposes at Ryerson and the only change will have to be the provision of electricity. We are writing to the Hydro Electric Commission for the preparation of a lighting plan for this type of building. I presume, from previous correspondence, that you will wish to have tenders called for the erection of this building. However, your knowledge of local conditions will be necessary to advise the Department in this regard. It is
presumed that there will be sufficient space in the present school yard for the new building. In orienting this building, please note that it is designed to face in a southerly direction, but that the wall of windows could be faced towards the east. I would suggest that you send in a small sketch of how you propose to locate the school on the present property. You should also indicate whether additional land will be required.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 27 with reference to the proposed new school building on the Perry Island Reserve. The Regional Supervisor, Mr. Morris was recently a visitor here and we looked over the proposed site for this building and he agreed with me that it would be the most satisfactory location. This location will be directly across the main Reserve road from the old school and is high enough to insure drainage. The site, however, is in the ownership of an Indian, Gilbert Tabobandung and I have arranged to purchase from him one acre of land at a price of $25.00. I am enclosing a tentative agreement of sale and would be obliged if you would have the proper document drawn up and submitted to me for his signature. Gilbert Tabobandung holds approximately five acres of land, having a frontage on the road of approximately 416 feet and a depth of 625 feet. This was allotted to him by resolution of the Perry Island Band Council dated August 6, 1942. I am enclosing a sketch showing the location also two copies of the information report.

There is a well at present close to the new school location and which will be on the land which it is proposed to purchase. It is my intention to have this well cleaned out and the water tested.

I am recommending that the building be erected by day labour and can obtain the services of a foreman carpenter whom I believe to be an exceptionally good man and have seen him at work in charge of other buildings. There are only one or two contractors in town who might be interested in putting up this building on the basis of tender and I have not much confidence in their work and believe that we would get a much better job done in the manner I have suggested and at perhaps...
less cost. I can very strongly recommend the man whom I have selected and whose name is Christopher Junck, a resident of Parry Sound. He will hold himself open for a few weeks and I would be pleased if final arrangements could be completed as soon as possible so that we may go ahead with the work and have the school, if possible, ready to open for the fall term.

No electricity is at present available on the Reserve but the Band Council have recently signed a resolution requesting that the Hydro Electric Power Commission extend their services to the Parry Island Reserve and I am taking this up with the Commission.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
May 27, 1949.

Mr. Samuel Devlin,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Ryerson Indian Day School

Your letter of May 10 has arrived, and the necessary action has been taken:

1. A memorandum has been sent to the Deputy Minister requesting approval for the hiring of Mr. Christopher Junck of Parry Sound, Ont., as foreman-carpenter at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

2. A request has been sent to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for all the materials required for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and residence, Plan 388. We have mentioned all the firms included on your information report.

3. You should proceed to have the well cleaned and tested as soon as possible, as it is most important to have a satisfactory supply of water before proceeding with construction.

4. As it will take approximately three weeks to one month before building materials start arriving, I do not feel you will be able to do much more than the excavation before the end of June. The cement usually takes at least three weeks.

If the cement arrives and Purchase Orders have not been issued for the lumber, then wire me and we can arrange for an authority for local purchase of the form lumber required for the foundation. Then Mr. Junck can at least proceed with this part of the building.
5. When the building has been started, please write me immediately, and I will send you a set of blueprints and specifications covering the installation of electrical wiring in this building. You can then obtain tenders from local electricians for wiring the building as it is erected. It will be cheaper to have it done then than to wait until next year when Hydro is available.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Ottawa, May 27, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Ryerson Indian Day School
Parry Sound Indian Agency, Ont.

Included in our 1949-50 Estimates is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room school and teachersage on the Ryerson Reserve, Parry Sound, Ont. This is to be a second classroom to the school already erected there. Mr. Indian Superintendent Devlin has recommended that this building be erected by day labour using a foreman-carpenter and local Indians. In his letter to the Department recommending that we employ Mr. Christopher Junck of Parry Sound, Ontario, at the rate of $1.50 per hour, Mr. Devlin makes the following statement:

"I am recommending that the building be erected by day labour and can obtain the services of a foreman carpenter whom I believe to be an exceptionally good man and have seen him at work in charge of other buildings. There are only one or two contractors in town who might be interested in putting up this building on the basis of tender and I have not much confidence in their work and believe that we would get a much better job done in the manner I have suggested and at perhaps less cost. I can very strongly recommend the man whom I have selected and whose name is Christopher Junck, a resident of Parry Sound. He will hold himself open for a few weeks and I would be pleased if final arrangements could be completed as soon as possible so that we may go ahead with the work and have the school, if possible, ready to open for the fall term."
I would recommend, therefore, that you approve the erection of this one-room school by day labour and the employment of Mr. Christopher Junck of Parry Sound, Ontario, as foreman-carpenter at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

Director.

Ottawa, May 27, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Ryerson Indian Day School
Parry Sound Indian Agency, Ont.

Included in our 1949-50 Estimates is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room school and teacherage on the Ryerson Reserve, Parry Sound, Ont. This is to be a second classroom to the school already erected there. Mr. Indian Superintendent Devlin has recommended that this building be erected by day labour using a foreman-carpenter and local Indians. In his letter to the Department recommending that we employ Mr. Christopher Junck of Parry Sound, Ontario, at the rate of $1.50 per hour, Mr. Devlin makes the following statement:

"I am recommending that the building be erected by day labour and can obtain the services of a foreman carpenter whom I believe to be an exceptionally good man and have seen him at work in charge of other buildings. There are only one or two contractors in town who might be interested in putting up this building on the basis of tender and I have not much confidence in their work and believe that we would get a much better job done in the manner I have suggested and at perhaps less cost. I can very strongly recommend the man whom I have selected and whose name is Christopher Junck, a resident of Parry Sound. He will hold himself open for a few weeks and I would be pleased if final arrangements could be completed as soon as possible so that we may go ahead with the work and have the school, if possible, ready to open for the fall term."
I would recommend, therefore, that you approve the erection of this one-room school by day labour and the employment of Mr. Christopher Junck of Parry Sound, Ontario, as foreman-carpenter at the rate of $1.50 per hour.

[Signature]
Deputy Minister

Mr. S. Devlin,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Parry Sound, Ontario.

This refers to your letter of July 29th in connection with your voucher 456 for Credit Voucher amounting to $241.75.

When your Labour Returns for the week ending July 9th and 16th were received, a Credit Voucher for $249.00, being the gross salary paid was made up and forwarded to Treasury for payment. This voucher has now been paid.

When your voucher was received, the case was brought to the attention of Treasury officials and it was noted that on your voucher you did not include the Income Tax deductions and Employers' Share of the Unemployment Insurance. We, on the other hand showed the Income Tax Deductions but not the Employers' share of the Unemployment Insurance.

The Treasury Branch are requesting that for every vouchered labour return you pay the Unemployment Insurance, both employers and employees share; and the Income Tax which should be sent to the local Income Tax Office, and then prepare a voucher for the amount of the Gross Salary paid plus the employers share of the Unemployment Insurance. Also quote the cheque number sent to the Income Tax office.
This means that in the case of these two pay lists the voucher should have read for $149.70, as the voucher for $149. has been put through. In order to keep the books straight you should place another voucher for 70¢ to clean up the Employers share of the Unemployment Insurance providing the employee concerned has had his stamp placed in a book. If the latter has not been done it should be done and your bookkeeping that far will be complete.

Trusting this information will assist you in keeping your books in order and in agreement with Treasury records.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Brown, Port Arthur, requests that the Department supply flooring, roofing, windows, doors and nails to the Indians of the Sand Point Reserve to enable them to complete a log school building which they intend to erect. The Indians intend to get out the logs and do the entire labour free.

Sand Point is situated on Orient Bay, Lake Nipigon, near the Ontario Government fishing station. It is in the centre of a tourist region. The Agent states that there are between 20 and 30 children of school age. Mr. Paget informed me that while he was there last summer he was frequently asked by Americans why the Government did not provide a school for the Indian children who are running wild around the place. He states that a school is urgently required for the Indians of this reserve.

The Agent has not furnished an estimate of the cost of supplying the above material, but I would like to advise that he be authorized to purchase the flooring, roofing, windows, doors and nails required, and also that he oversee and be responsible for the carrying out of this work.

If the school is erected, it will be necessary to supply desks and equipment and also pay the salary of a teacher. These Indians are members of the Red Rock Band and have no funds of their own. The cost of the material now asked for and the equipment of the school could be provided for out of the current year's estimates.

Sir,

You should oversee the work from time to time as it progresses and see that it is being carried on and completed according to your instructions. The Department will be pleased to hear from you at a later date as to the progress that is being made.

REPORT UPON SANITARY INSPECTION OF PUBLIC SCHOOL GEORGIA.

No. Town... at Sand Point Ont.
Indian Village Sand Point Township... District of Thunder Bay Date... June 15th, 1921
(Shore of Lake Nipigon two miles from Maidamid, Ont., Ont. Fishing Station)

1. Grounds - (size, suitability, drainage, character of soil, etc.)
No definite limits to grounds; gradually sloping to lake shore a few yards distant sandy soil; drainage good.

2. Water Supply - (source, protection of well-top, drinking cup, bacteriological exam.)
Dipped from lake at shore. Spring approximately 100 yards behind school should be safe source of supply. Samples taken from lake at shore and from spring (reports to follow when analyses completed) Lake water at shore exposed to pollution from village. No drinking cups as of set (type, size, cleanliness, covers, protection from flies, when cleaned.)

One pit closet (log building with one seat) for common use by boys and girls. Fairly clean, but no lids on seats, and not fly-proof.

4. School Building - (materials, number of rooms, accommodation and size of rooms.)
One room in log building which is the house for the teacher and her family. School room is 20 x 16'. Partially sloping ceiling, height at lowest point 8'.

5. Interior of Rooms - (blackboards, number, etc., windows (no. & area), blinds (general cleanliness, seats, type, etc.)
One piece black oilcloth nailed to wall seats of rough pine. Walls and ceiling covered with coarse brown paper. Rough pine board floor. Room generally unattractive and depressing.

6. Heating, Lighting and Ventilation -
One wood-burning box stove for heating purposes. Lighting by means of two windows previously mentioned. Ventilation by means of windows and doors.

7. Wash places - (type, towels, washing slates, etc.)
Nil. at present; because teacher states number of children have skin troubles and running sores. Ordinarily one or two basins and towels.

8. Has talk on sanitation been given to pupils?
No; because would be of no benefit. The only measures which would be of any use would be compulsory instruction in habits of personal cleanliness and in home hygiene.

9. Average number of girls and boys: On roll- 16 boys, 12 girls, total 27. Average, 7 boys, 6 girls, total 13. June 15/21, 6 boys, 8 girls, total 14.

10. Recommendations -
Separate building for school. Separate closet accommodation for boys and girls. Compulsory Instruction in personal and home hygiene. Weekly inspection and supervision by supervision, whose orders are to be enforced by R.C.M.P. If necessary. Attendance at school to be compulsory; also children to be required to come to school in cleanly condition or to be compelled to clean up while there. On the date of inspection (June 15-21) many of the children were in an extremely dirty condition, most of them having 'nits' in their hair.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of the 14th instant, re "Complaint sent to the Indian Agent, Port Arthur," I have the honour to advise that, on the 15th inst., I visited the "Sand Point" Band of Indians located on the shores of Lake Nipigon about two miles from Macdiarmid. I was accompanied on this visit by R.C.M.P. Constable W.M. Campbell who is stationed at Nipigon, Ontario.

There are approximately 12 houses at Sand Point, also a few tents and tepees; and the number of Indians is said to be from 75 to 100. The surroundings are about the same as are found in any Indian village, and I do not see how a higher standard of cleanliness can be enforced unless a R.C.M.P. Constable visits the place about once weekly throughout the year.

The attached school inspection report will indicate that the present school building is a mere makeshift; and I would say that the majority of the school children were in a deplorable dirty condition. The teacher told me that her work is most discouraging as the children remain away from school if she endeavours to exercise the slightest authority over them. The names of 37 children appear on the school-roll (15 boys and 12 girls). 14 of these (6 boys and 8 girls) were present at school and were inspected on June 15/31. Four were excluded from school until discharging sores and other skin affections were cured (one other child not on the roll being forbidden to attend school for the same reason) and I may say that so many children has "mite" in their hair that if they had been excluded for this reason the school would be practically deserted.

Of 13 absences from school, four were inspected, and one child Michel Metamagosis age 6 years, was found to have a large chronic discharging ulcer on the left index finger, which was swollen to about twice or three times its normal size. This child's left eye was also infected, and discharging pus; and on the left side of his neck was a discharging gland. He was in a most wretched condition and should immediately be removed to a hospital (I was told afterwards that one had been in the same condition as his left hand but I neglected to look at his feet). Five other children (pre-school age or names not on school-roll) were inspected. A child Harry Metamagosis, age 3 years (brother of Michel M.) was found to be suffering from pustular conjunctivitis affecting both eyes. This child will likely become totally blind if the condition is not treated properly, and he should immediately be sent to a hospital. The parents should be compelled to submit to examination to determine whether or not they show evidence of venereal disease.

The Department of Indian Affairs should engage with one of the doctors at Nipigon or Jolliet to visit Sand Point once a week to inspect the school and endeavour to clear up the discharging sores and skin affections from which so many of the children are suffering. It is apparently impossible to change the habits of Indians, but something may be done with the children if they are enabled to attend school in a clean and attractive building, also if they are compelled to be present at school, and to be clean during the time they are there. The school curriculum should devote as much time to elementary personal and home hygiene as is devoted to reading, spelling etc. For the obvious need of these people is the practical application of knowledge regarding cleanliness, both of the person and in the home whether it be tent or house. As Dr. Robertson truly states "the Indians suffer unspeakable evils from lack of sanitary education" and if the children were allowed to grow to adult life careless and ignorant of the most elementary rules of decent living, their condition will become worse instead of better.

Yesterday
Yesterday, the 16th, I saw Mr. W.R. Brown, Indian Agent at Port Arthur and I gave him an outline of conditions as I found them at Sand Point. I also attach for your information a copy of some written recommendations which I have today sent to Agent Brown.

I have the honour to be, sir?

Your obedient servant,

Sgn. G.L. Sparks.
