Sir:

The enclosed letter, which is self-explanatory, was just received today from Miss Genevieve McAteer, teacher at the Sand Point Indian Day School. As you will note the teacher complains about the price of merchandise at that point. I advised her that provisions could be purchased at Port Arthur at a very much cheaper price and advised her to send me in an order which would be placed with a wholesale company in Port Arthur, and her merchandise could be shipped direct to Sand Point.

As you will note the teacher is asking for an increase of $5.00 per month, and she will resign if the Department does not grant her this wish. Personally I would not recommend granting this increase and would recommend accepting her resignation.

In my opinion, the Department is singularly fortunate in having a lay teacher of Miss Hamer's resourcefulness and energy. In commenting upon the cleanliness of Indian children, the writer takes into consideration the fact that the children are Indians. What might be satisfactory to the writer, however, falls far below Miss Hamer's ideals, and so she personally superintends the bathing of her pupils. I was glad to hear that the Department had made her an allowance for her social work among the Indians, because I believe, salary, etc., being anywhere near approximately equal, she would sooner teach in an Indian school than in a white one.

Most of the children attending Sand Point School live close at hand, but Miss Hamer finds that they are badly underfed. She would like to give them something hot at dinner time.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

You may possibly be wondering why the teacher at Sand Point was anxious to secure a transfer to some other school, especially in view of the fact that her services have been quite satisfactory to Mr. Burk and myself.

But, as you know, (and as the Department, I am glad to feel, desires), the missionaries take a great interest in these little schools, and are particularly glad that the teachers act as catechists and set an example, in a religious way, both by action and precept.

Poor Miss Hamer happens to be the daughter of a mixed marriage, and her piety is not so fervent as might be hoped; or, at least, the missionary thinks that it is not, which amounts to the same thing. When the missionary gets into the average Indian village, all are agog, and the teacher is the first to get to church in the morning. Poor Miss Hamer, unfortunately, has managed to be ignorant of the Father's vis (she says she cannot hear the church bell when he rings it) and has failed, on a number of occasions, to turn up to mass in the morning. Hence she is persona non grata to the good Father, which is too bad, because she is really interested in Indians.

The situation will clear itself up in due course, because the attendance at Sand Point has fallen so low that the school will most likely have to be closed next summer. Miss Hamer will then be looking for a school. I am very favourably disposed to her, myself, and, if Lacourcière resigns his job at Whitefish Bay (Kenora) at the end of the year, I have asked Mr. Edwards to keep Miss Hamer in mind. Or, if Miss Lavallee quits Birch Island at the end of the year, you might like to give Miss Hamer that position.

I have spoken to a good many people about this young lady. Above all, she would like to be employed as a field matron, organizing the Indian women into sewing circles and the like. In such work she would be an outstanding success, I should think.

With kindest regards,

Yours very sincerely,

REPORT.

Re: Frank Esquiega - Indian - Sand Point Indian Reserve - Bitten by ferocious dog.

First Report:

Acting upon instructions from Corporal Bebb F.H., N.C.O., in charge of the Nipigon Detachment, on the 13th inst., I left our patrol post C.N.R. to Stevedors on route to the Sand Point Indian Reserve.

Information had been received from Peter Esquiega, by telegram, to the effect that a ferocious dog had bitten his son Frank, age about 18 years, and he requested that we come at once and get a doctor.

Arriving at the Indian Reserve I learned that the dog who attacked and bit the above named was owned by Miss Violet Hamer, the Indian schoolteacher.

On making enquiries in regard to the incident I learned that Miss Hamer was coming across the lake to the Indian Reserve with the dog and small sleigh, on seeing another dog, the dog of Miss Hamer's bolted with her, whereupon she called for the assistance of the above named who was in the vicinity.

F. Esquiega grabbed the dog by the harness and led it about 15 yards when the dog attacked him from the rear, sinking his tusks into his left leg above the ankle. On turning upon the dog to try and protect himself, the dog bit both of his hands, however he managed to grab his collar and shake him off.

During this affair Miss Hamer got frightened and ran away to a house, at the present time F. Esquiega is lying in bed with the wounds from the dog.

Steve Nockwingus a reliable Indian on this Reserve stated that this dog of Miss Hamer's was dangerous to be at large and the children were afraid of the dog, he considered that this dog was a nuisance, and had attacked several of the Indians in the past, but succeeded in scaring them.

Jerry Belanger states that he has been attacked by this same dog, and grabbed by the hand but did not cut the flesh on account of him having very thick mitts on.

Antoine Bouchard Jr. states that Miss Hamer's dog attacked him about one month ago, but being able to ward the dog off with a stick he was not hurt.

Amelia Bouchard states that the same dog ran after her and she was only able to reach the house for safety when it caught the back of her skirt.

Antonette Nockwingus states one day she was going to the school, when the dog chased after her and if it had not been for some boys who chased the dog off with sticks and stones he probably would have attacked her.

Margaret Nockwingus states she was knocked down by the dog and gave her a great shock and made her terrified.
Upon investigating the poor attendance at the school I found that this dog was the cause of it, as the Indian women were afraid to let the children go to school for fear of being bitten.

During my visit to this Indian Reserve on the 1st March, last, in company with Peter Bouchard this dog attacked the leader of our dogtrain, and in attempting to drive it off it grabbed my wrist, and owing to the thick mitts I was wearing I only received a small cut.

I told Miss Hamer that the dog would be better destroyed to save any further trouble, and that I intended doing this for the sake and safety of the Indians and children on that Indian Reserve; as it was considered a dangerous and ferocious animal to be at large, this dog was known to be running loose most of the time on the Reserve.

Although Miss Hamer did not wish to have the animal destroyed, I saw that the dog was shot before leaving, and that it was carried into the bush for burial.

I returned to the Detachment at 11.00 a.m. of the 14th inst.

EXTRACT from Inspector Greening's Report on his inspection of the SAND POINT INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on June 10, 1932.

Original on File 9-10-6.

I am distinctly disappointed in the work done by this school during the past year. The Indian parents have plainly failed to cooperate with the teacher. Attendance has been poor, and some of the children are very neglected. Two of them (one the Chief's son) seemed to be attending school while suffering from scabies.

Whatever may be the representations made to the Department at Ottawa, it is the considered opinion of Mr. Agent Burke and myself that the advantage being taken by the Indians at Sand Point of this school most decidedly does not warrant the expenditure being made.

It would be much better to close the Sand Point School at the end of the present term, and open a school at Grand Bay next autumn. In company with Mr. Agent Burk the Inspector called in at Grand Bay. There is a partially completed residence that would do admirably for a school until the building at Sand Point can be brought over the lake.
Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Replying to your letter of the 21st instant, in regard to Miss Hamer.

I have discussed the matter with Mr. Burk, so that this letter contains the views of both of us.

There is no doubt that Miss Hamer is "in wrong" with the Indians at Sand Point. It may be partly her own fault, as her tongue has not always been too carefully bridled, but there is certainly no doubt that her zeal in seeing that the children get to school and attend in a clean condition has helped to make the situation worse. As I have already told you, she is "non grata" with the Missionaries, (I have never been able to find out why, but I suspect that she has been talking too much), and it would be altogether inadvisable to send her to Grand Bay. It would militate decidedly against its success. If Miss Hamer is to be given another school, it had better be out of this Agency, because Mr. Burk tell me that, Father Hingston having heard that she was likely to be sent to Hobert, wrote him to ask that such move be not put through.

I have given the young lady a good talking to, and Mr. Burk tells me that he thinks she will take it to heart. Miss Hamer has done good work among the Indians, and has always been genuinely interested in them. I asked Mr. Burk particularly if he thought she ought to be let out altogether, or whether he thought that her past services warranted another school. He thinks that she deserves consideration, but he does not want to send her to Grand Bay or to Hobert. I should, myself, be inclined to give her a chance, but if Father Hingston does not want her at Hobert, there may be similar objections to her being sent to any Jesuit mission. You might like to give her another chance, or you might decide not to bother with her any more. I have, personally, no interest in her other than a belief that she is capable of good work as a teacher if she is acceptable otherwise.

With kindest regards,

Yours very sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter enclosed from Mr. Burt, Sagamore Agent at Port Arthur, advising that my services no longer required.

This is a serious matter and I feel that owing to circumstances I am entitled to some consideration.

In the first place, I knew positively that when this was written Robert was vacant, and I asked for his school. Mr. Burt refused me, and I cannot understand his attitude.

Last year Rev. Dr. Cartier wanted to move me—was going at Sand Point—petitioned 13 families out of 14—asking that I be left at this school. I wrote Mr. Ferrier for a transfer—and he replied that he had none—but asked that I remain at Sand Point.

I have served Dept. and Indians faithfully for three years. At Sag Bay and Sand Point. My whole life has been given over to the work during my time as teacher here—twenty-four hours per day—I have been ready to work for these people.

Nursing the sick—and dying—hours at a time—caring for expectant mothers & babies—& supporting...
I sent children to hospital in winter, handing out drugs and clothing, and rations, besides teaching all day. Last winter I formed a club and under my supervision all children were clothed and windows dressed as well. This necessitated my being up from 7 a.m. until 12 midnight for over 3 weeks. I have gone down in health in two years, and only recently the doctor advised a rest, but I am forced to work. This year my father & mother are my hands to support and I feel that after three years in the bush among Indians, I am attacked by wolf and hate to leave because of some personal grudge the priest may have, who only visits the reserve at the most every 3 months, and then only for a few hours—never calling at the school or giving any attention to the moral welfare of teacher or children. But we feel the need of spiritual guidance and are unable to receive it.

It would be obliged if you can see your way to look into this thing. I am unable to do anything. You have my records for teaching which Mr. Greening advised were satisfactory, that in itself should be proof of my earnestness of purpose.

Will take a school of any denomination as far north and as isolated as you can find anywhere and would be pleased to have the opportunity of proving.
That I am turn over good work of any kind.

Have been off for holidays the month and would be prepared to return again.

Praying that you will give this consideration and believing in the Dept's fairness to an honest worker.

Believing me,

Respectfully,

T.S. Hamner

P.S. Have the late Mr. Service's letter on hand in which he asked me to continue at Sand Point.

If you have any other kind of work that you feel might be fitted for Sand Point, I believe that Sand Point has every chance to make a very fine and have done practically everything an Indian Agent can do - Sales, field, matron, record service work.

W.S.

Dear Mr. Burk,

Your letter of October 17th, regarding the services of Miss Homer as Field Matron, was referred to me, and I may say that this was the first notification I had received of the fact that Miss Homer's services have been paid for from medical appropriation.

When Miss Homer was notified by letter of August 25th, that there was no vacancy in which she could be placed as teacher, it was taken for granted that her services were dispensed with. However, I understand a cheque for $13.50 has been sent to her for the month of October as her name was included in your pay list. Before the November pay list is made up I would appreciate it if you will let me have your views regarding retaining the services of Miss Homer, particularly in view of the fact that she is not living on an Indian Reserve, and it is not our practice to provide Field Matron service for Indians who may be passing through small towns such as MacDiarmid.

I shall be pleased to have your suggestions as I must confess I am quite in the dark as to why Miss Homer's services should be continued.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Inspector Greening, in his report on the McIntyre Bay Indian Day School, dated June 23, 1938, states that there are only five pupils enrolled at this school and that five pupils were present on the day of the inspection.

I should like to have from you an explanation with respect to the comparatively small enrolment at this school, in view of the fact that there were 18 enrolled when the Inspector made his last inspection on October 8, 1938. I should add also that it is not the intention of the Department to keep schools open and in operation with an enrolment of five pupils. This is a matter that should be discussed with the teacher in charge and with the Indian parents. The taxpayers of Canada simply cannot afford to employ Indian day school teachers to take charge of schools with such small enrolments.

You might report on this matter just as soon as you can conveniently do so.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 14th ultimo, in connection with Inspector Greening's report on the McIntyre Bay Indian Day school dated June 23rd, 1939, I beg to report that project on this reserve has been closed for some time and in consequence the large majority of the families on this reserve moved to Gull Bay reserve to cut pulpwood. They were also engaged on other pulpwood work on Lake Nipigon.

For the Department's information, I may say that I just received a communication from the McIntyre Bay reserve advising that the majority of the families have now moved back and are now working at the Breakwater construction and other work on the reservation. It is anticipated the band will have permanent work on this reserve in the very near future consequently attendance will be back to normal by the time school opens on September 1st.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, February 17th, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, informing the Department that Miss Genevieve McAteer, teacher of the Sand Point Indian Day School, has not resumed duties since leaving the school early in November, last, on account of her mother's illness, and requesting that you be authorized to obtain the services of another teacher to succeed her.

In reply I beg to say that the Department desires that this school be reopened at as early a date as possible, and you may, therefore, arrange to engage the services of a teacher, having the necessary qualifications, to succeed Miss McAteer. We will allow salary at the same rate as was paid Miss McAteer, viz. $55 per teaching month. Please give this matter your early attention and forward the name, qualifications and experience of any applicants for the position for the approval of the Department.

You should also inform Miss McAteer that her services are being discontinued. She was paid salary to the end of October 31st, 1927. If there is any balance due her for the time she taught before leaving the school in November, I shall be pleased to have a statement from you as to the number of days taught by her, in order that any balance can be paid.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.
Ottawa, March 6th, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, enclosing the applications which you received for the position as teacher of the Sand Point Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that Miss Mona K. Duggan, Annan, Ont., has the better qualifications, and you may offer the position as teacher of the Sand Point School to her, at a salary of $55 per teaching month. We note that Miss Duggan has a permanent second class certificate, and three years' teaching experience. You should arrange with her to begin duties as soon as considered timely by you to have this school reopened. In writing Miss Duggan offering her the position, you should give her as full information as possible regarding living conditions and any supplies it may be necessary for her to take in with her.

If for any reason Miss Duggan is unable to accept, you may offer the position to Miss Kathleen G. O'Hara, who holds a second class certificate, and has had teaching experience. You should take the necessary action as soon as possible in communicating with the above named teachers in the order mentioned. It is hoped that Miss Duggan will accept. Please inform the Department later as to whether she accepts the position at Sand Point or not, and, if so, the date upon which she begins duties.

We note you have advised Miss McAteer, the former teacher, that her services are discontinued.

The applications which you forwarded are returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur,
Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Replying to your letter under date of Nov. 20th. I beg to state that I am still without cheques for salary due. Mr. Burk's reply as quoted by you, does not help me any. Dear Sir,

I received a letter from Mr. J.G. Bark last week, in which he stated that he had asked that my cheques should be forwarded to my credit in my bank, and had been promised that that should be done immediately.

It has, however, not been done, and I am still minus salary due for last April and July. I think you will agree that it is high time this matter was settled, and in view of the near advent of Christmas, I need the settlement. Having taken advice on the matter, I am informed that there are two possible courses open:

1. To sue the Macdonald Postmaster for illegal and unlawful detention of these cheques, together with interest and damages.
2. To get the Indian Dept. to notify the Bank that payment of these cheques is cancelled, and issue me direct a new cheque for the total due.

I am not anxious to tread the road of litigation, but it is necessary that I should obtain the money so long withheld. I therefore appeal to you to stop these cheques and issue me a new one for the total due, so that I may have it before Christmas.

In view of the fact that this is money earned, I do not think my request is unreasonable, and I would point out that if the department had sent my cheques to the address I gave on my form (Callander) as they did when I was in Macdonald, the situation would never have arisen.

The position now is, that I have not yet received my wages for work.
done, and that repeated correspondence, involving many letters to various people involved, at some expense and considerable worry has not produced any effect.

I have therefore no alternative but to try other methods to recover that which is my just due, but before doing so, I would ask the Department once again to simplify matters and save trouble, by paying me the amount due, and cancelling the cheques that have never reached me, and which were sent to an address where I was not.

Thanking you in anticipation of an expedited settlement,

yours very truly,

PORTARTHUR ONT 17 1137A
SECV DEPT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

MR HAINES CHEQUE HAS REACHED BANK OF MONTREAL PORTARTHUR

M Morton
Ottawa, December 17, 1934.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the following telegram:

"Mr. Haines' cheque has reached Bank of Montreal, Port Arthur"

(Sgd.) M. Morton.

It is presumed that this wire is an answer to our night letter of the 14th instant addressed to you.

I cannot understand why the telegram reads "cheque". You will remember that there were two cheques. These were specifically mentioned in official letter of September 27th and your reply dated September 29th.

The Department has been caused a great deal of inconvenience owing to the manner in which these cheques were handled. Repeated letters for the last three months have not yet brought the matter to a satisfactory conclusion. Please advise me immediately on receipt of this letter if both the cheques referred to in official letter of September 27th have now reached the Bank of Montreal, Port Arthur, and, if not, you should state the reason for the totally unnecessary delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Ottawa, December 17th, 1934.

Sir,-

On receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, the Department wired Mr. Agent Burk and I am today in receipt of the following telegram:

"Mr. Haines' cheque has reached Bank of Montreal, Port Arthur"

The telegram, as you will note, only refers to "a cheque", while the Department was under the impression that there were two cheques. I am again writing Mr. Burk today.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland.
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

A. T. Haines, Esq., M. A.,
c/o Mrs. J. Hearl,
Callander, Ont.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
Dec., 20th, 1934.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th inst., No. 9-10-3, regarding wire received in connection with Mr. Haines' cheques, I wish to advise that both cheques have reached the Bank of Montreal at Port Arthur, and such was the message sent in the wire from this office.

It was evidently an error on the part of the Telegraph Company in using the singular rather than the plural.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Mr. J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of Dec. 17th re. salary cheques, and note the contents. I may say that I received last week end a communication from Mr. Burk in which he stated that he had been informed "over the phone" that my cheques had been deposited in the bank. I immediately communicated with the Manager of the Bank for confirmation of this, but up to the present date, no such confirmation has been forthcoming.

I also appreciate your point about there being two cheques, which is perfectly correct.

Should I obtain confirmation of the deposit of these cheques to my credit, I will inform you at once, as no one is more anxious to terminate this unfortunate episode than I am. Meantime, the position remains unchanged! Please be assured that I am appreciative of the Department's efforts to have these cheques delivered to the proper owner.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

September 8, 1936.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Mr. N. Van Hatten transferred from Whitesand to McIntyre Bay, from September 1st, 1936, at a salary of $85 a teaching month. He succeeds Miss Susan A. Fex.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
Nov. 4, 1936.

Attention - School branch

Sir:

With reference to Mr. Norman Vannatten, who was teaching at the Whitesand Indian Day School up to July 15th of this year, I beg to report that he was transferred this fall to the McIntyre Bay Indian Day School. Up to the present time he has not received a check for the fifteen days he taught in July at the Whitesand Indian Day School. I would appreciate very much if a check could be forwarded to him at the McIntyre Bay Indian Day School, Lake Nipigon, Via MacDiarmid, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, November 7, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, I would point out that Mr. Norman Van Hatten was allowed a full month's salary as teacher of the McIntyre Bay School, and it is considered that this amount should reimburse him for any period he may have taught the Whitesand School during the month of July.

Please let me know at which schools in your Agency you consider the teachers should remain on duty until July 15th and not reopen the schools until September 15th. You should also state if this arrangement results in a better attendance at these schools. On receipt of this information, the Department will decide whether or not we should approve of this arrangement.

In the event of our approval, it should be distinctly understood that, in future, you should write about the first of May each year and make a definite recommendation regarding each school in your Agency that you desire kept open until July 15th. This information is necessary in order that the Department can make the necessary arrangements for paying the teachers for the period they are on duty during the month of July. A separate letter should be forwarded regarding each school at which this arrangement is recommended.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Sir,

Dear Kind Mr. Phelan,

So far I have not been able to make out any requisition for school material, owing to the fact that I have not been able to secure any blanks. Navigation will soon close and then it will be some time before we can send mail or receive any. Would you kindly send at your earliest convenience about fifteen dozen lead pencils to this school?

I hope to send in a complete list later.

Respectfully yours,

A.A. Tex

Ottawa, December 12, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of requisition dated the 26th ultimo for supplies for the Grand Bay Indian Day School.

A number of books requested by the teacher are considered unnecessary and are not being supplied.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of one ordinary alarm clock, 2 gallons floor oil, 12 bars soap, 12 cups, 1/2 pint enamel and 1/2 gallon varnish.

With reference to the articles requested on the enclosed two pages of the requisition, I would appreciate if you would check them carefully and advise what you consider are absolutely necessary. As you are aware, our funds are limited, and while many of the articles specified might be useful in the school, at the same time, it is considered that progress might be made without them.

The tooth brushes and camphorated chalk will be forwarded to the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Sir:

In official letter of the 9th instant, I referred to the receipt by the Department of a requisition for supplies for the Grand Bay Indian Day School. In forwarding this requisition, which was dated March 30th, last, Miss Fex gave the express office of the school as Nipigon, and the supplies were sent to that point.

The shipment is at Nipigon unclaimed, and the Express Company was requested to forward it to Macdiarmid. The Express Agent at Nipigon now advises that the Express Office at Macdiarmid will not be open until May 24th and that, in any event, prepayment of 27 cents covering the express charges from Nipigon to Macdiarmid will have to be made.

Please give this matter your immediate attention and arrange for securing the shipment for Miss Fex. Any necessary charges should be paid by you, a receipt obtained and a voucher forwarded to the Department.

You should point out to teachers in your Agency the importance of giving the correct express address when forwarding requisitions to the Department.

June, 23, 1927.

Sir:

On a recent visit to the Sand Point and Pic Reserves I noticed the schoolrooms were not equipped with clocks. Both the teachers enquired if it would be possible to have one placed in the schoolrooms.

I would personally recommend purchasing these two clocks, as a great number of the children cannot tell the time.

These clocks would cost approximately $10.00.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, June 27, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, requesting that a clock be supplied for each of the Sand Point and Pic Indian Day Schools. In reply I have to say that the clock we supply Indian schools is known as the Big Ben type of alarm clock. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a clock of this type for each of the above schools. Please forward a separate voucher, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of a clock for each of the schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Indian Agent,

December 3rd, 1927.

Sir,

Regarding the school situation in this Agency I beg to submit the following report:

At the Sand Point Reserve two old log buildings were purchased this summer to conduct a temporary school. The buildings are still answering the purpose of a temporary school and residence, but are not suitable for permanent buildings. Mr. F. H. Paget, Chief Accountant, of our Department, inspected these two buildings last summer and could vouch for their inadequacy as permanent school buildings. On my last visit to this Reserve the majority of the Indians had left for their trapping grounds leaving their wives and children on the Reserve to take advantage of the school.

As this school has proved to be a success I would recommend the construction of a new school and residence next spring on the Sand Point Reserve.

G. Burk,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 19, 1927.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 3rd instant, recommending the erection of a new school and teacher's residence on the Sand Point Reserve, I beg to say that, in view of the fact that purchase was made last summer of a building for school purposes and also a building for use as a teacher's residence at this point, the Department is not prepared to provide the funds necessary in the erection of a new school and residence next summer. It is thought that the work can be carried on under existing arrangements for the time being.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I hope you will excuse my long delay in writing to thank you for your kind efforts and success in getting the necessary grant for the Pic Indian Day School. I am making regular trips of inspection and find the work progressing splendidly. The foreman-contractor, a respected man, is most capable and conscientious. He expects to have the school completed by the end of June or the first week in July.

The lack of good schools in this Agency has long been a subject of public comment, more particularly is it so now that we are up against new problems and facing a very serious situation. The fur catch has decreased 30% during the last 3 years and to make matters more serious the Game & Fisheries Department are also cutting down on beaver and otter, the mainstay of the Indians' hunt.

The only solution for our Indians is more education to teach the younger generation to become useful citizens. As you have helped me out so splendidly in the past, a fact that I greatly appreciate, I sincerely hope I may bank on you for even more assistance in this matter. We need more schools in this Agency and need them urgently.

Although school is being carried on at Sand Point conditions are most unfavourable. Both the school and residence were constructed some 30 years ago and are most decidedly not suitable, although filling the bill for the present. As this Reserve is isolated, it will be very difficult to retain the services of a competent teacher under the existing circumstances.

If it is at all possible I would strongly urge the construction of a combined school and residence at that point. Would it be possible, Mr. Ferrier, for you once more bring this matter up, as I feel confident, through your influence, it could be accomplished.

Sir:

With reference to earlier correspondence and conversations when you were in Ottawa last week, I have now to authorize you to erect a classroom and teacher's residence at Gull Bay and also Sand Point. The work may be proceeded with when timely. The Department relies on you to supervise the activity and to see that there is no unnecessary expenditure.

You should purchase the materials required, after securing competitive prices from the best sources of supply, when forwarding properly certified accounts in duplicate, in favour of the firms awarded the business, you should attach memoranda showing those asked to quote and the prices quoted. The bill of material and your experience last year in connection with the Pic Indian Day School should guide you as to what is required. I understand that the Department Architect has provided you with specifications and has given you his advice.

You may engage the services of a competent foreman-carpenter, who will be responsible for the erection of the buildings and who will be paid by the day. Indian and other local labour should be employed as far as possible. Labour returns, in duplicate, should be prepared, as usual, when timely, you may apply for an accountable cheque, with which to pay for the labour, and also for a supply of labour returns. The plans which were forwarded to you last year should be followed as closely as possible.

When these two buildings are being constructed, you should visit the work when possible for the purpose of overseeing the activity.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

RE: Wettlaufer Mixer, Hamilton, Ont.

With reference to the construction of the two combined Indian Day Schools and residences, which are to be erected in the very near future at the Sand Point and Gull Bay Reserves, I beg to report I have just had a long personal interview with the foreman-contractor and we both came to the same conclusion it would be far cheaper to purchase a small concrete mixer which would, undoubtedly, pay for itself during the construction of the two schools. On completion of the two above mentioned schools the mixer could be shipped to our warehouse and kept in storage for future work.

The Indians in this Agency and especially on Lake Winnipeg are hunters and do very little building, consequently they would be very slow workers. Under the circumstances I would recommend that the Department purchase a small Wettlaufer Mixer, which holds 3 cubic feet and costs $265.00.

If the above meets with the Department's approval I would strongly recommend that one be ordered immediately and shipped to Port Arthur.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Sept., 24th, 1929.

Sir:

With reference to the construction of the new combined Indian Day Schools and Residence on the Sand Point Reserve, I beg to advise there is approximately 6 inches of water in the basement under the teacher's residence.

I consulted the foreman-contractor, Mr. McBride, and we decided it would be advisable to put in a tile drain 100 feet long, which will cost approximately 6 cents per foot for the tile and $15.00 for labour, a total cost of $21.00. In order to successfully drain the basement I would strongly recommend that authority be granted immediately to proceed with this work.

An early will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Superintendent,
Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, September 26, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, relative to the providing of drainage for the basement of the teacher's residence portion of the Sand Point Indian Day School building.

In this connection I have to say that you may arrange to put in a tile drain. It is noted that it will require 100 feet of tile, at a cost of approximately 60 cents per foot and $15 for the labour. You should arrange to have this drain installed, and you should see that a satisfactory job is completed. It is hoped that when this drain is installed it will overcome any future difficulty in keeping the cellar under the teacher's residence portion of the building in a dry condition.

Please forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the tile for the drain and the labour in having same installed.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Ottawa, May 6, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, requesting authority to construct a fence around the school property at the Sand Point Indian Day School, and giving an estimate of the cost.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I just returned from Lake Nipigon on my last tour of inspection before freezeup. Mr. Greening, the R.C. School Inspector, was rather anxious to inspect the Lake Nipigon schools before the freezeup. We were certainly very lucky as we encountered a terrific hail and snowstorm 15 minutes after we tied up at the dock. Mr. Greening certainly was frightfully sick going up the lake, as the weather was very rough, but I must confess once he reached dry land and consumed a few cups of tea he was as lively as a cricket.

Mr. Greening seems to be a very fine fellow and I am sure is a very good school inspector. He was very favourably impressed with the good work Miss Hemer is doing at Sand Point not only in school hours but also socially.

The classroom at Sand Point and also the kitchen and bedroom really should be kalsomined. I was just wondering if it would be possible to stretch a point and order a furnace for Sand Point. A kalsomining furnace would really pay for itself in a few years, as you burn approximately twice the amount of fuel with box stoves and this combined with the features that the classroom should be kalsomined every year when stoves are used, and the everlasting dragging in wood and fixing fires which undoubtedly disturbs the pupils, would more than counterbalance the expense of the furnace.

If the Department would consider a furnace for Sand Point we could get one installed for a very reasonable figure. At this time of year when the plumbers and tinsmiths are not rushed a furnace could be installed for approximately $300.00. If you could possibly see your way clear to authorize this expenditure I can assure you it will be very much appreciated.

Weather is much colder at the Head of the Lakes and is hard on one's coal bin.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

It is, perhaps, not within the writer's province to criticize, but it has always struck him as decidedly odd, upon entering a school up-to-the-minute in every other respect, to see shabby old stove pipes stretching out crazily over the ceiling. But at no time has the contrast struck him so forcibly as when visiting Sand Point after having been at Gull Bay. In the latter, a hot air furnace heats the school and residence very comfortably, the objectional stove pipe is eliminated, and the classroom is a joy to the eye. At Sand Point, a room, with exactly the same potentialities, has an ugly wood stove right in the middle of a splendid classroom. Apart from the aesthetic side, I think it would be an advantage to change the heating of Sand Point from stoves to furnace. In fuel, alone, a furnace should pay for itself in ten years at the most. If one were to include the replacing of stove pipes and the frequent calsomining resultant upon smoky little stoves, I believe the cost of installation would be covered in half that time. And precious moments would not be wasted while trying to recall the attention of the students from the, (to them, entrancing) sight of a fellow student putting some more wood on the stove.

REPORT

Re:- Investigation at the Sand Point Indian Reserve -
Department of Indian Affairs -

First Report:

Acting upon request from J.G. Burk - Indian Agent to make a general investigation at the Sand Point Indian Reserve, and also to ascertain if Indian Constable T. Bouchard had removed his horse barn off the school property situated 20 feet from the school. He had been told by the agent last winter and also at treaty time to remove this barn, so I was requested to give Bouchard a reasonable period to remove same.

On the 15th inst I proceeded by car via Macdiarmid, and by boat to the Sand Point Indian Reserve.

I learned at the reserve that four old people were having quite a bit of sickness, but not in a serious condition.

Several families were away picking blueberries, and the Indians present were mostly catching fish for food, and as a supply for the coming winter. On information received from the Indian Agent I informed them that the Department would supply them with a reasonable amount of salt and salt kegs to put up fish for the winter if they only applied for same. Most of the Indians at this reserve are living under destitute circumstances throughout the year.

On interviewing Indian Constable Tom Bouchard in regards to the horse barn, he stated that he had not removed it and showed me where it was, and said he did not intend moving it until he was paid for his time. On giving him a definite period until the 15th October to remove the barn, he became very insolent and said he would see Burk the Indian Agent about it.

This barn is a danger to the health of the children at the school. Indian Bouchard has now been given definite instructions to remove the barn. He is a very poor Indian Constable, and if he does not remove this barn by the 15th October I would recommend that this Indian lose his appointment and another Indian appointed at that reserve instead. The Department would then have to pay other Indians to move the barn.

I returned to detachment at Nipigon at noon of the 16th inst.

Sir:

With reference to the Grand Bay settlement which was established last fall I wish to state we now have 15 families living on the Reserve. Approximately 15 acres of ground has been cleared and from 8 to 10 acres will be planted in the near future.

For the Department's information there are approximately 22 children on this Reserve who should be attending school. The majority of the families have moved from the Sand Point Reserve to better their living conditions at Grand Bay.

The school on the Sand Point Reserve should be moved to Grand Bay. I have had an expert inspect the school and find it can be sawed and moved in 3 separate pieces. A large scow could be obtained and the school moved from Sand Point to Grand Bay for approximately $300.00. I would strongly recommend the school being moved during the summer holidays, as there will be approximately 25 to 30 children should attend school at Grand Bay.

One of the moving contractors in Port Arthur, advised he could not take the contract under $300.00. In conclusion I may say if all goes well I expect to have the school moved to the Grand Bay Reserve, a distance of 45 miles by the end of next month. With reference to the cost of moving the school, which I figure will cost approximately $450.00, I hope to keep within my estimates, and if all goes well I am quite convinced we can move the school for approximately $450.00.

March 11th, 1933.

Dear Norman:

You will no doubt wonder why I communicated with you by long distance today. I was frightfully worried, and did not know what to do about the school. In the first place I got in touch with a house mover who advised he would move the school for $200.00, if the department would pay the cost of the tractor, to and from the Reserve, and also feed the men. Counting the freight rate on the tractor and equipment, and feeding of the men, and his contract price of $200.00 would bring the price up to approximately $1400.00. I considered I could not the school for $450.00. I did not, however, figure on using $1400.00 on food supplies to build a temporary school, and make a grade from the beach to allow the school to be pulled from the beach to the Reserve.

Then I first made enquiries regarding the freight rates on the tractor I was advised I could ship it for $65.00. I was flabbergasted when I found out I had to pay $150.00, nor did I figure paying $50.00 insurance on the tractor, and $50.00 for timbers. I figured we could cut timbers at our sawmill, but the moving contractor advised green timbers cannot be used. Consequently I was obliged to purchase 4 10 x 10 timbers, 80 feet long, at a cost of approximately $40.00. I did not figure the cost of labour involved in fixing the school permanently on the Reserve, that is time and labour involved in building a foundation, etc., which all costs money.

I am attaching herewith the approximate cost of moving the school and do hope we will be able to get extra funds. Moving this school is a big undertaking, but when you consider the school cost approximately $5000.00, and is only going to pack and ruin, it is a very good investment.

With reference to my official letter enclosed, regarding the tractor, I really believe it would be a very good investment. The tractor
I considered this cost too high, and consequently made the above arrangements.

I would appreciate it very much if the Department would advise if it will be possible to secure additional funds to have the building moved. The school cost approximately $3000.00 and is practically new. For the Department's information I may say that the majority of the families from Sand Point have moved to the new Reserve at Grand Bay.

Sir:

I beg to refer you to previous correspondence of June 4th, 1932, and your reply of June 7th, File No. u-9-5, regarding the moving of the Sand Point Indian Day School to the Grand Bay Reserve, which I figured would cost approximately $450.00.

For the Department's information I may say I spent $149.99 for supplies to compensate Indians for work performed in clearing right-of-way on the Grand Bay reserve for the purpose of moving the school from the ice onto the Reserve; also considerable expense was involved in grading the ground from the beach to the Reserve, and putting a small bridge over a slight ravine on the Reserve where the school would have to pass over. We also constructed a temporary residence on the Grand Bay Reserve for the teacher, which was included in the supplies amounting to $149.99. I do not believe this expenditure should have been charged to the moving expenses.

For the Department's information I may state I got in touch with the C.N.R. Freight Department and advised them I was anticipating shipping a 10 ton tractor and equipment. I was informed the freight would be $60.00 one way. Yesterday when the tractor was loaded with moving equipment, the total weight amounted to 12,000 one way, which was extremely high. I did everything possible to have the rate reduced, but was unable to meet with any success. It will cost approximately $100.00 to have the tractor shipped back to Port Arthur, and about $100.00 for supervision, $50.00 for new 10 x 10 timbers, $25.00 for rental of tractor, $25.00 for the man to drive the tractor, $50.00 for insurance—total including supplies mentioned above $225.00.

When I first sent in my estimate of $450.00 I did not figure on $50.00 insurance on the tractor, and the freight rate, as previously stated, was exceptionally high.

Referring to previous correspondence you will note I obtained a figure from a moving contractor to move this school for $800.00. This did not include freight on tractor, and moving equipment which would be paid by the Department, or the board of the man.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th inst., No. 4-2-5, regarding the moving of 2nd and Point School. In reply I wish to state it was my intention at the time of receiving authorization to move this school by snow. When the snow was moved from the skids I discovered it was too old to undertake this exceptionally large load. It would have been necessary to tear down the building, and to rebuild it. This would have entailed a great deal of expense. Consequently I interviewed Chambers, McQuillan, & McCaffrey, who did a great deal of towing on Lake Nipigon in the winter months during construction. They advised me if the services of a competent house mover could be obtained this building could be easily moved on the ice. I obtained a contract price of $3000.00 from Frank Love, who advised he could move the building from any point on the lake, and set it up on a wooden foundation for $2000.00, on condition that the Department supply tractor, and pay freight charges on same. This charge appeared excessive.

I then got in touch with Mr. P. Carlow, a man with a great deal of experience in moving houses, who advised he would undertake the work, supply all equipment consisting of house jack, sleighs, pulleys, cables, etc., for $6.00 per day—total amount not to exceed $1200.00. I again interviewed the above mentioned firm, who informed me they considered this arrangement should be satisfactory. They advised me not to undertake the work myself.

It was my intention to move the school in February, but owing to the severe weather, it was impossible to do so. I was travelling on Lake Nipigon from February 1st to 10th, during which time the temperature average was 40 degrees below zero, with strong winds.

Upon my return to MacBride on February 10th, I got in touch with Captain McKay, who is winter fishing on Lake Nipigon, and asked him to send word when he considered she was fit to commence operations. I received word on March 5th, advising that the lake was in good condition for moving, with approximately 8" of snow. The equipment
The Secretary

was loaded on the car the following day. Mr. Carlough and the tractor driver left for Sand Point on the 9th. I followed on March 11th.

Unfortunately we encountered most unfavourable weather, with exceptionally heavy snow fall, and very strong winds. Within 6 days over 28 inches of snow fell, and drifted so hard it would actually hold the 10 ton tractor. It was at this time, upon the advice of the tractor driver, that I sent a night letter to the department asking if it would be possible to purchase a small tractor to assist. The purchase of a small tractor had been approved in official letter of August 17, 1932 for the Quill Bay Reserve, and could be transferred easily to Quill Bay—40 miles distant.

It was necessary to employ extra Indian labour for shovelling snow. We made very good progress the first two days until we got out to the open lake, where the snow had drifted. After several days attempt to continue moving, I considered it unwise to go on, as we were moving only a few hundred feet each day. We worked constantly from daylight until dark.

I returned to MacDiarmid, leaving the building, packed upon skids, with a watchman in charge. The ice was tested several hundred feet from the school, and was found to be 32 inches of solid blue ice. I consulted several reliable men at MacDiarmid, who agreed with my opinion that the school is perfectly safe for the present, and can be easily moved immediately the snow melts.

For the information of the Department 3 cars of hay were conveyed on sleighs from MacDiarmid to the Quill Bay Reserve, a distance of 72 miles, where there was a depth of 12 inches of snow water on the ice.

I considered it advisable to ship the heavy 10 ton tractor to Fort Arthur, as the charge of retaining same was too much. The school can be moved by 2 teams of horses, or a smaller tractor, when there is no snow.

In conclusion I wish to say that I regret this delay, but feel I have done my utmost to move this school at the least possible cost. I also have the assurance that the Grand Bay Indians will give such
The Secretary,

Further assistance as is necessary without remuneration. It is not considered at present that the snow on Lake Nipigon will melt until the 2nd week in April, and navigation open before the middle of May. I am keeping in constant touch with Macdonald, and will leave immediately word is received that the snow has melted.

As a last resort, I will have the Indians take the building apart in sections, and remove to a near by island to be taken across in the summer. This, however, is not anticipated.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. G. Buck,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 29, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, reporting the difficulty met with in moving the Sand Point Indian Day School building to the Grand Bay reserve and enclosing photos showing the work in progress.

The Department has noted the exceptional weather conditions and the heavy snow which has interfered with the work. It is hoped that you will use every effort to have this building moved to its future site on the Grand Bay reserve and that there will be no danger of loss, owing to a sudden change in weather and the ice becoming unsafe to bear the weight of the building.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands to have the work of completing the removal of the building carried out at the lowest expense and as early as weather conditions permit. It is thought that there are certain accounts in this connection, which you could forward, in order that payment can be made before our books close for the present fiscal year. It is noted that you considered it advisable to ship the heavy tractor to Port Arthur. Accounts for freight charges on the tractor, for any other expenses in connection therewith and for any labour to date could be forwarded, in triplicate, properly certified. All these accounts should be dealt with previous to the end of the present month, and, if received by the 6th of April next, they could be paid from this year's Appropriation. Please give this matter your prompt attention.

I note you have the assurance that the Grand Bay Indians will give the necessary assistance in the moving of the building, without remuneration. I would urge that you use your utmost endeavour to have the school moved to Grand Bay without resorting to the necessity of taking the building apart and removing it to a near island to be taken across in the summer.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Sir:

I have your letters of the 30th ultimo and the 4th instant, enclosing vouchers in connection with the expenditure incurred in moving the Sand Point Indian Day School to Grand Bay. Cheques in payment of these accounts will be issued in due course.

It is noted that there will be further accounts rendered which, you state, should not exceed a total of from thirty to forty dollars. I would request that you render all accounts in connection with the moving of this school as soon as possible. The expenditure in this matter has been greatly in excess of the first estimate submitted by you. In your letter dated June 4, 1932, you stated the cost of moving this building from Sand Point to Grand Bay would not exceed, approximately, $500.00, while the total expenditure to date has been in the vicinity of $1,300. In view of the need for strict economy and the necessity of making a great reduction in our Appropriation, it is doubtful, if we had been aware that the cost would be so high, if authority would have been granted to move the building.

It is noted, when the building arrived at Grand Bay, that it was necessary to move it to a better site. It is considered a proper site should have been selected for the building before it was moved.

You should endeavour to have this building placed on a satisfactory foundation and all the moving equipment returned to Port Arthur. You may incur an expenditure not exceeding a sum of $50.00 in putting the school in good condition and carrying out minor repairs. There will be no funds available for calculating or decorating. After the work of placing the building in good condition has been completed, you should forward an account, properly certified and in triplicate, covering the expenditure, which should not exceed the above authorized amount.

It is hoped that this building will be ready for occupation when the schools re-open after the present summer holidays. You might also inform the Department regarding the teacher who will conduct the classroom work.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant requesting information concerning the payment of an insurance premium on a ten ton tractor used for moving the Indian School across Lake Nipigon.

Reference has been made to the Orders-in-Council quoted by you, and it is found that these refer to the placing of insurance on Government property, whilst the question under review does not involve Government property, but was to cover private property in the form of a ten ton tractor which was rented by our Agent for the purpose of moving the school referred to above.

The tractor was rented from Donald A. Clark, of Port Arthur, Ontario, whose account therefor was paid by cheque number 6015, dated 28th June last.

For your information I beg to quote the following paragraph from our Agent's letter of the 4th April last:

"For the Department's information I may say I was compelled to insure the tractor, as the owner would not allow the heavy tractor to go over the ice until it had been insured."

I trust the above information explains the matter to your satisfaction.

Yours truly,

Referring to your letter of July 11th, No. 9-9-5, regarding the Sand Point School building which was moved to McIntyre Bay, I beg to report I overlooked the necessity of constructing a chimney and also the providing of a cement foundation for same. At present an improvised chimney built by the foreman is in use, but will not be sufficiently safe to use during the winter months.

I am extremely pleased to report that this building has been put in first class condition by the Indians—floors scraped and varnished, walls kalsomined, a splendid foundation constructed, and the school and residence has the appearance of a newly constructed building.

The cost of constructing a new chimney and foundation for same would be approximately $75.00 to $100.00. As this Band have not sufficient funds to cover the cost of building this chimney, I would recommend an additional grant to cover this expenditure, as I feel it is absolutely essential to the safety of the building. I would appreciate it very much if you would inform me at your earliest convenience regarding this matter. I may say this will be the last expenditure required for this school.

Sir:

MacDiarmid.

The cost of handling from MacDiarmid to the school, not charging transportation by boat will be $10.00. I have included, however, $500.00 in the estimates for the construction of a basement next year.

I trust the Department will authorize the installing of this furnace which can be put in immediately. The cost will be approximately $300.00.

Dear Mr. Sutherland,

When I was at Ottawa recently, I discussed with you the matter of the school at McIntyre (sometimes called "Grand") Bay. Sir:

Referring to our verbal telephone conversation of recent date, may I draw your attention to the appropriation of $900.00 to install a new furnace and construct a basement at the McIntyre Bay Indian Day School. For your information, I may say, that owing to the fact that the school is located near a weeping bank which has been gradually falling in, I was informed by an engineer that it would be better to wait until the fall of the year, as the summer rains would make any excavating impossible, and to ascertain just how far the bank would fall in during the summer months. Consequently, I decided to postpone the building of the basement until the Fall.

I may say, that I secured a contract from the C.N.Rly for from 5000 to 10,000 ties to be cut on the new timber limit, adjacent to the McIntyre Bay reservation but as this limit was cancelled, the contract also had to be cancelled. I would strongly recommend that authorization be granted to build the basement under the school as in this way we will be able to create work for the band.

In conclusion, I might add, that the grant was secured for this work in 1935 also, but was also cancelled.

I have the honour to be, sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

FT. WILLIAM.

TEACHERS RESIDENCE.

SAND POINT SCHOOL.
Referring to your letter of the 3rd instant, File No. 9-10-l, relative to re-opening the Indian day school at the Sand Point Indian Reserve, and requesting me to rent a suitable house for the teacher and to furnish her with cooking utensils. In reply I beg to advise I was very fortunate in being able to rent two suitable buildings, one for the teacher's residence and the other for the classroom. Both buildings are situated in the middle of the reserve. This property is fenced in and is suitable for children's recreation grounds.

I rented the above two buildings at a rental of $25.00 per month for each building. The owner is willing to sell the property and the two buildings for $300.00, and will be satisfied to take a rental of $50.00 per month until the property is paid up. The two buildings could not be replaced for less than seven or eight hundred dollars.
Ottawa, May 25, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, informing the Department that Miss Genevieve McAteer began duties as teacher of the Sand Point Indian Bay School on the 17th instant. It is also noted that you have been able to obtain a suitable house for the teacher's living quarters and a house in which to carry on classroom work - both buildings being centrally located and the grounds fenced and suitable for children's recreation.

The Department approves of the renting of the buildings referred to for the sum of $25 per month each, and will pay the rental at that rate for a period of six months. It is understood that, at the end of that time, the amount paid as rental will cover the full purchase price of the buildings, viz.: $300. You should prepare and forward from time to time properly certified vouchers for the rent due, and, when the 6 months' period has elapsed, you should prepare and forward, in duplicate, a quit claim deed (blank forms for the purpose enclosed) for the transfer from the owner to the Department of the two buildings with the grounds surrounding same. A proper description of the plot of land should be filled in in the deed.

The continuing of the school permanently will depend upon the success achieved during the first 6 months it is in operation. It is hoped there will be a full and regular attendance of all Indian children of school age and that the teacher will meet with every success in her work.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

With reference to my letter of the 23rd ultimo and your reply of the 25th, your file number 9-10-1, regarding two buildings purchased on the Sand Point Indian Reserve to be used as a teacher's residence and the other for a schoolroom, I beg to advise I have just received word from Mr. J. Nicholson informing me that he is now willing to sell the house and a large woodshed for $250.00. This also includes a first class canoe which the teacher could use when going to and from MacDiarmid where the nearest postoffice is located—a distance of approximately two or three miles.

Personally I would recommend the Department purchasing the woodshed, as it only is only a few hundred feet behind the schoolhouse, and would be very useful for storing wood. As the road from the Reserve to MacDiarmid is very wet I would consider it advisable to purchase the canoe also.

The building purchased for the school is just a very few feet from the residence. This building was purchased from Mr. Nicholson's son for $100.00. I have already advised him that he would receive two months rent at $50.00 per month until the building was paid for, when a quit claim deed will be filled out and sent to the Department.

Mr. Nicholson Sr. expects to build a new house at MacDiarmid and would like to be paid in full for his property. Personally I would recommend the Department purchasing this building as the same could not be erected under six or seven hundred dollars.

If the Department favours the purchase of this building the cheque could be sent to Mr. Nicholson, MacDiarmid, Ont.

I am enclosing herewith vouchers covering the rental of the schoolhouse and the purchase of the school residence.

Referring to your letter of the 3rd instant, File No. 9-10-1, relative to re-opening the Indian day school at the Sand Point Indian Reserve, and requesting me to rent a suitable house for the teacher and to furnish her with cooking utensils. In reply I beg to advise I was very fortunate in being able to rent two suitable buildings, one for the teacher's residence and the other for the classroom. Both buildings are situated in the middle of the reserve. This property is fenced in and is suitable for children's recreation grounds.

I rented the above two buildings at a rental of $25.00 per month for each building. Ottawa, May 25, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, informing the Department that Miss Genevieve Roateer began duties as teacher of the Sand Point Indian Day School on the 17th instant. It is also noted that you have been able to obtain a suitable house for the teacher's living quarters and a house in which to carry on classroom work - both buildings being centrally located and the grounds fenced and suitable for children's recreation.

The Department approves of the renting of the buildings referred to for the sum of $25 per month, each, and will pay the rental at that rate for a period of six months. It is understood that, at the end of that time, the amount paid as rental will cover the full purchase price of the buildings, viz.: $500. You should prepare and forward from time to time properly certified vouchers for the rent due, and, when the 6 months' period has elapsed, you should prepare and forward, in duplicate, a Quit Claim Deed (blank form for the purpose enclosed) for the transfer from the owner to the Department of the two buildings with the grounds surrounding same. A proper description of the plot of land should be filled in in the deed.

The continuing of the school permanently will depend upon the success achieved during the first 6 months it is in operation. It is hoped there will be a full and regular attendance of all Indian children of school age and that the teacher will meet with every success in her work.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

Miss Isabella Ruxton, Teacher of the Saugeron Village Indian Day School, applies for an increase in salary. She at present receives salary at the rate of $600 per annum, plus bonus of $150 - a combined salary and bonus of $750. There is a teacher's residence provided and fuel allowed. She asks that her salary be increased to $900 per annum, and states that the salary now paid her is out of proportion to that paid other teachers in the rural white schools of the district.

Miss Ruxton has taught this school for 12 years; she has a Non-professional Third Class Certificate. The Public School Inspector speaks very highly of her work: he states that her methods of teaching are very good and that a great deal of originality is shown in the school work. He adds that his visit was very satisfactory and that the pupils were making marked progress.

The teachers in the two other schools on this reserve receive salaries as follows:

Mrs. Robb, Scotch Settlement, $650 and bonus $150 - total $800.
J. T. Wallace, French Bay, $800 and bonus $150 - total $950.

As Miss Ruxton is giving as good service as the other two teachers on the reserve, I would beg to recommend that she be granted an increase of $50 in her salary for the school year beginning September first, next, which would give her the same amount as is paid Mrs. Robb at Scotch Settlement.

The salaries of all the teachers on the Saugeron Reserve are paid from Band Funds, and the interest at the credit of this band could stand the increase in salary.

You should ascertain from him whether he will reside in the teacher's residence during the winter and, if so, you should arrange at once to have a sufficient quantity of dry wood supplied to last until the Spring. You should obtain this wood as cheaply as possible and, after the wood has been delivered at the residence, you should forward properly certified vouchers in duplicate covering the expenses incurred. The Department will expect you to give the matter of the purchase of a sufficient quantity of wood your prompt attention after you are definitely assured by Mr. Knechtel that he will use the residence this winter.

Relative to furniture, I would be pleased if you would prepare a list of what you consider is absolutely necessary for the use of the residence and, if possible, you should give an approximate cost of same. This matter should receive your immediate attention and you should state what is required to make suitable living accommodations for the teacher. The furnishings will, of course, only be supplied provided Mr. Knechtel intends to use the residence this winter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Saul Putnam, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill,
Ont.

Saugeen Village School.

Mr. W. M. Knetchel, teacher.

Attendance very fair. 26 on roll, average for April 20. A number of the Indians complained to me that this teacher uses liquor, and that he does not have proper control of the pupils during recess and play hour. They ask that a married man be engaged. I could find no evidence in support of the liquor complaint whatever. I have instructed Agent Robertson to report to the Department should he find any truth in the statement. Mr. Knetchel states that the play hour is personally supervised. I found the discipline in the classroom excellent.
Ottawa, June 19th, 1933.

Sir,

Following his recent visit to the Saugeen Indian Day School, Inspector McGookin reported that he had received complaints that the teacher uses liquor and does not have proper control of the pupils during recess and play hours. Mr. McGookin further stated that he had instructed you to advise the Department if you found any truth in the above report.

Please advise, as soon as possible, if you made inquiries regarding Mr. Knechtel. In replying, you should state definitely if you consider his services should be retained for the academic year 1933-34.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes.
Acting Secretary.

Hon. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill, Ont.
Chippewa Hill, Ont. June 26th. 1933.

Sir,

I have the honor to refer to Department letter No. 31-2-I, dated June 19th, regarding complaints received against the teacher of the Saugeen Indian Day School.

I beg to say, I have investigated the complaints made in the above mentioned letter and found no truth in them. Mr. Knechtel, the teacher, has always had perfect control of the pupils both in the class room and on the play grounds, neither the truant officer or myself has ever saw any sign of liquor around the place. Mr. Gane, the Inspector, states that this teacher is one of the best in his district. I would consider that his services should be retained.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Don. Robertson,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, June 29, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, with reference to complaints received regarding the teaching services of W. M. Knetchel, teacher of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School.

In this connection it is noted that, after investigation of the complaints, you find no truth in them and that you consider Mr. Knetchel's services should be retained. It is further noted that the public school inspector stated to you that he is one of the best teachers in his district. The Department will approve of his re-engagement for the coming school year, with salary at the same rate as he at present receives. Please inform him accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

D. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill,
Ont.

Chippewa Hill, Ont. November 21st. 1933.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the Saugeen Village Indian Day School will be closed from November 20th. to November 23rd.

I beg to say, the teacher, Walter Knechtels, mother died on November 10th. The funeral will be held on November 23rd. Under these circumstances I have closed the school until after the funeral.

I have the honor to remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Don. Robertson,
Indian agent.

Ottawa, December 15th, 1926.

Sir,-

I enclose herewith the December quarter salary cheques of the teachers of the Saugeen, French Bay, and Scotch Settlement Schools. Please hand these cheques to the respective teachers before the schools close for the Christmas holidays.

You should arrange with each of them to prepare and forward to the Department the usual quarterly return.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Saul Putnam, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ont.
Ottawa, December 16, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that we are today appointing Mr. Walter Knechtel as teacher of the Saugeen Village Indian Day School, to begin duties on or about January 3rd next. The salary allowed him will be at the rate of $100 per teaching month. Mr. Knechtel has a permanent second class certificate and nine years' teaching experience.

If he resides in the teacher's residence, any fuel required is to be furnished him, and I have to request that you will arrange to see that there is the necessary supply of fuel on hand. If necessary to purchase any at the present time, you should arrange to see that a good grade of dry wood is obtained at the lowest possible cost.

I shall be pleased if you will give Mr. Knechtel any assistance you can upon his taking up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Saul Putnam, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill,
Ont.

That the Village School house and grounds be repaired and improved as follows: a new double door on the entrance. The plaster in the basement repaired. I have the honor to state that the pump at the Indian Village School has been out of working order for about six weeks before the school opened and as the water was impure I found it necessary to engage Henry Ritchie to repair the pump, the cylinder of which was split, clean out the well, and repair the platform which was decayed. It will be necessary to have a new cistern in the near future. I would suggest that it be done in the dry season and that it be brickled. On account of the sandy nature of the soil stone can not be used and a wooden cistern decays very rapidly.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed you will please find tender for the removing of the old furnace in the Indian village school Saugeen, Ontario, near Southampton, and the installing of a new furnace in its place.

We find on going over this building which the writer did on Tuesday with one of the best heating engineers of the City of Toronto, that when this original heating system was installed, it was as near perfect as could be, but the people in charge of running the system did not understand it and that is the reason of it being burnt out so soon. The trouble has been that they have not been giving the furnace the air it requires, or have they ever fired the furnace, that is, there to heat the ventilating shaft, that forces circulation, and after looking everything over, I think you will always be up against this same proposition, and in figuring out our proposition, we are still going to use the old system, but have added an independent system to circulate from the inside, so that if they shut off the outside air we will still be able to heat the building satisfactorily, and not endanger the burning out of the furnace.
You say in your letter to us, that the Indian agent will remove the old furnace. We prefer doing this ourselves, as we expect to use part of the walls that are in use in the present system. I find that on looking over the tinsmith and metal workers in Southampton, and Port Elgin, that their experience in this kind of work has been very limited, and while it will cost a few dollars extra for railroad fare, and hotel expenses, I think it better to handle this from Toronto. There we have men who know how to handle this kind of a job, and finish it in such a way that it is done and no need of going back after the cold weather comes.

Frustrating to be favored with your valued order,

we are,

Gentlemen:

Some months ago I wrote re. the new furnace put into the Sagamook Village School not heating satisfactorily.

Yesterday with weather about zero the highest we could get the school was 62°. This is not fit for pupils to sit in so long, and though I sent them off to run about in the basement to try to keep them warm, some of them are ill after it; in fact I was almost sick myself after being chilled so long. It was only about 20° at 9 o'clock.

To-day the highest we could make it by noon was 62°. After that the sun aided in putting it higher.
As stated in the previous letter, the only register in the room is way up in the wall, and there is no way of getting the children to it. (Of course this should not be necessary if the room were comfortably furnished.) Were the furnace placed near the centre of the room, and registers put in the floor, it might work.

The old furnace was very unsatisfactory. It took hours to warm the school, and consumed a great deal of wood. This one takes hours to heat up and then does not throw enough.

The weather was only about 30° yesterday so you see how it will be when the thermometer registers 16° to 20° below zero even more.

These Indians having been obliged to pay for the furnace, it seems too bad that the children have to suffer from the cold. I have had to send them out to exercise, but this means lost time for the pupils.

Had the Agent Mr. Stout been consulted, he would not have allowed it to be put in as it is, as he was aware of the unsatisfactory place of the old one. The furnace was put into Sunday without him being consulted.

So otah settlement has a new furnace, which gives good satisfaction and does not require a great amount of fuel.

Trusting this will receive your immediate attention.

Yours sincerely,

J. Robertson Teacher.
