Sir,

The teacher in her annual report on the Saugeen Village Day School in reference to the heating has prepared a tabular statement of temperatures of the class-room on February 12, 13, 14 and 19. The results shown are not satisfactory, and the temperature is certainly not high enough for comfort. It is noted that the temperature is very low at 9 o'clock and rises rapidly during the day. This shows conclusively that the fires are not being properly attended to or the temperature would be maintained at a normal point at all times. It is impossible to heat a class-room the size of the one there with its very high ceiling unless the building is at the right temperature on the opening of the school. The furnace is capable of properly heating the building, it being considerably larger in capacity than is necessary for this purpose. The trouble, therefore, appears in the attention given, and possibly the fuel used is not dry. Ottawa, March 21, 1917.

Sir,

A report has now been received from the Indian Agent of Saugeen Reserve in reference to the furnace installed by you in the village school there, and according to the report the furnace is not giving satisfaction.

The wood used is dry beech and maple, in four ft. lengths, the fire being kept in banked-state during the night with the fresh air from the outside closed end inside circulation established. The fires are said to be renewed each morning between 7 and 8 o'clock and efficiently maintained during the day, and notwithstanding this, the temperature is reported as being too low to enable them to carry on school work, the temperature ranging during the school hours as follows, viz., Feb. 12th, from 20° to 55°; Feb. 13th, from 22° to 54°; Feb. 14th, from 40° to 65°; Feb. 19th from 16° to 65°. From the temperatures shown it must be admitted that furnace is not showing satisfactory results as guaranteed by you, and I have, therefore, to inform you that the Department cannot accept this as being satisfactory, and require that you will efficiently demonstrate its capacity to do the work guaranteed.

It is now too late to make the test this year owing to the delay of the Agent in answering the Department's enquiry of Jan. 24th last and which reached us on the 12th instant. The test must, therefore, be made during the next Winter in presence of an official of this Department at a suitable date which will be arranged.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Kir-Ben, Limited,
Furnaces, Etc.,
Almonte, Ont.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, March 21, 1917.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant in reference to furnace at village school, Saugeen Agency, and in reply to inform you that the Kir-Ben Company has been written to in reference to this and informed that a practical demonstration of the furnace must be made to ensure satisfaction, and as it is now too late in the season, owing to the delay in your report, to have this effectively done, the test will necessarily take place next Winter.

The reason given for not using the ventilating furnace is not considered satisfactory, as the wood could be cut to suit the furnace at a very small cost, which would be allowed. It is also necessary to have a certain quantity of dry light wood with which to raise the temperature in the mornings or at other times when a sudden demand for heat is needed.

It is quite certain that in this school, as in every other, that satisfactory results cannot be obtained without efficient attention, and the lack of this is generally found to be the reason for unsatisfactory heating.

A copy of the Department's letter to the Kir-Ben Company is enclosed for your information.

Your obedient servant,

T. A. Stout, Esq.,

I beg to report that in September the 19th and 20th I made an inspection of the village school, Saugan Agency, it having been reported that the furnace was not giving satisfactory service.

The furnace and ventilation system was carefully examined and found in good working condition and amply capable of satisfactorily heating and ventilating the building if given the proper attention, (which it apparently does not get.) There is only one change which might be made to advantage, viz., the lowering of the combined hall and cloak-room registers to floor line, to permit of the children warming and drying their feet there when coming in wet and cold, which might be an advantage for this purpose but would not otherwise change the conditions.

There are twenty-seven pupils enrolled with an average attendance of sixteen, which is reported as unlikely to be increased. The class-room is 25 x 41' with accommodation for 63 pupils, thus providing considerable more than double the room space required. There are eight large windows in class-room having a combined glass area of about 216 square feet, and without storm-sash to protect the windows from the direct outside temperature, and in addition some of the sash is broken, and in one instance will require a new sash.

Recommendations

I would therefore recommend that storm-sash be provided for all the class-room windows, the damage sash be made good, that one new front door be provided and fixed in position, hall register lowered, and would suggest that as the class-room is more than twice the capacity at present required, (or in the near future) a partition be built, shutting off the unnecessary portion with the consequent saving in fuel which would itself pay the cost of the change in two or three years.
The estimated cost of the repairs is as follows:

Storm-sash and repairs to windows, $153.00
Partitions, 115.00
Front door and setting 10.00
Changes to registers, 10.00

Total $293.00

Architect.
October 2nd, 1913.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that it is considered necessary to provide storm-sash for all class-room windows at the village school, Saugan Indian Reserve, a new sash to replace the broken one; also a new front door, unless this can be repaired economically.

The storm-sash should be made of 1/4 inch material, glazed with medium sized glass, hinged at top and fastened with proper hook fasteners where required. Ventilation openings should be provided in the bottoms of each sash, the sashes to be painted two good coats before being hung.

Prices should be obtained from persons in the vicinity doing this work and submitted to the Department for consideration that the work may be authorized if the prices are found reasonable.

You are also authorized to have the registers in hall entrance and boy's cloak-room lowered to the floor height and a tin register box placed in the stack to make this satisfactory. This should be completed as soon as possible, so that the furnace will be ready when required.

With reference to the ventilation, a hinged door should be placed over the fresh air opening in furnace so that the air in question only may be used during excessively cold weather, the door to be controlled by a chain and pulley set where convenient for this purpose. This work to be done as early and as economically as possible.

Your obedient servant,

T. A. Stout, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill, Ont.

Miss Ruxton, teacher of the Saugeen School, in her annual report for the fiscal year ended March 31st, last, states that the desks are in fair condition, but require to be painted and the teacher's desk needs a coat of varnish.
